Villagers remember past actions, and events echo years later as the story spans multiple generations.

Silent Hill 2 is a single-player survival horror game, and remake of the original Silent Hill 2. The story follows James Sunderland, who travels to the fog-shrouded town of Silent Hill after receiving a letter from his late wife, Mary, asking him to meet her at their “special place.” As James explores the town, he encounters disturbing monsters, hostile environments, and other characters whose motives and sanity are uncertain. His search leads him through apartments, hospitals, historical sites, and abandoned streets while unraveling a mystery that blurs the boundary between memory, guilt, and reality.Gameplay focuses on exploration, resource management, and combat. Players navigate semi-open environments while solving puzzles and uncovering story clues in documents and environmental details. Combat is primarily melee-based, with weapons such as wooden planks, pipes, and knives, though firearms are available later. Ammunition and healing supplies are limited, encouraging careful management. Enemies vary in behavior and resilience, requiring different tactics to avoid or defeat.The remake uses an over-the-shoulder third-person perspective instead of fixed camera angles, affecting both exploration and combat. James can perform heavier melee combos and improved dodges, while firearms allow for more precise targeting. Inventory management is streamlined, with separate categories for weapons, healing items, and puzzle objects. Saving progress is done at typewriters placed in safe rooms, retaining the series tradition of fixed save points.Puzzle-solving remains a central system, requiring players to collect keys, decipher codes, or manipulate environmental objects to progress. Difficulty levels can be set independently for combat and puzzles, altering enemy aggression or puzzle complexity. Environmental interaction is emphasized with physics-based objects, dynamic lighting, and weather effects that obscure vision and sound. Secondary systems include multiple endings determined by player choices, health management, and how James interacts with the world. Exploration of optional areas and thorough reading of notes or observing items can influence the outcome. Dialogue sequences are linear but character behavior and James’s responses may subtly shift based on player actions.While the narrative and structure follow the original Silent Hill 2, the remake alters level layouts, enemy placement, and pacing to match the new presentation.
This compilation includes:For Nintendo Switch 2 this is the first release of the game.

Theatrhythm: Final Bar Line is a single-player and multiplayer rhythm game that brings the long-running Theatrhythm: Final Fantasy series to consoles. The player forms a party of characters drawn from across the Final Fantasy franchise and plays through music stages that recount iconic battles, adventures, and journeys from the series’ history. Each song corresponds to a playable level, and the player’s timing and accuracy determine both the performance of the music and the progress of the characters on screen.Gameplay is structured around three primary note inputs: taps, holds, and directional flicks. These notes appear along different stage formats. Battle Music Stages use a four-lane interface where party members face waves of enemies, with simultaneous notes and faster sequences introduced at higher difficulties. Field Music Stages feature a single scrolling lane that mimics exploration across a landscape, requiring careful tracking of hold notes that rise and fall with the melody. Event Music Stages, returning from earlier entries, play cinematic sequences from Final Fantasy titles while players follow a line of notes across the screen.Each cleared stage rewards experience points for the chosen party of characters. Over 100 characters can be unlocked, each with unique stats, abilities, and roles in combat. Characters can attack, heal, or cast spells automatically depending on their abilities, which are activated by hitting notes correctly. The player can build teams to suit specific strategies, combining characters to boost damage, improve survival, or earn more rewards. Monsters and bosses appear during Battle Music Stages, and defeating them requires consistent accuracy to maximize damage.Progression is tied to Series Quests, which allow players to follow curated sets of songs representing different Final Fantasy titles. Completing objectives within these quests unlocks new tracks, characters, and treasures. Rhythmia points are accumulated as an overall score, measuring the player’s progress through the game’s massive soundtrack of over 350 songs. Additional content expands the library with music from spin-offs and other Square Enix titles, offered through deluxe and downloadable content editions.Secondary features include local co-op and online multiplayer modes. In Pair Play, two players can share the same screen and cooperate to clear songs. In Online Multi-Battle, up to four players compete for the highest score, while sending “bursts” that disrupt opponents’ note patterns. Customization options allow players to change button layouts, difficulty levels, and visual styles to suit preference. CollectaCards, unlockable artwork, and other cosmetic rewards provide incentives beyond music completion.

Dwarf Fortress is a single-player construction and management simulation game; a modern remake of the classic Slaves to Armok: God of Blood - Chapter II: Dwarf Fortress (2006) ASCII-based freeware release. The game takes place in a procedurally generated world where the player guides a group of dwarves in building and maintaining a settlement. The setting is high fantasy, with civilizations, histories, religions, and myths generated uniquely for each playthrough. The player’s role is not to control individual dwarves directly but to assign tasks, designate construction, and manage resources while the dwarves act independently according to their skills, needs, and personalities.The central mode, Fortress Mode, challenges players to establish and expand an underground stronghold. Dwarves gather wood, mine stone, forge metal, and farm crops, all while fending off threats such as hostile wildlife, goblin invasions, and subterranean horrors. Managing food, drink, and shelter is critical for survival, while growth requires assigning specialized professions, training soldiers, and balancing industry with defense. Catastrophes, whether from combat, structural collapse, flooding, or disease, are often inevitable, and part of the game’s storytelling.Each dwarf has detailed statistics, skills, and personal traits. Their happiness and mental state are influenced by their environment, relationships, and experiences. Players must monitor needs such as food, alcohol, rest, and emotional fulfillment, since unhappy dwarves may cause disruptions ranging from tantrums to full rebellion. Military management introduces squad formations, training regimens, and equipment assignments, giving the player control over the defense of the fortress while still relying on dwarves’ autonomous behavior.Progression occurs organically as resources are stockpiled and industries developed. Smelting, crafting, and trading allow the fortress to produce wealth, which attracts migrants and nobles, increasing complexity and demands. Trade caravans from other civilizations provide opportunities for exchange but also expose the fortress to political entanglements. The economy grows more intricate with workshops, guilds, and mandates imposed by rulers, requiring the player to balance ambition with survival.The simulation extends to natural processes, with detailed models for weather, temperature, fluid dynamics, and geology. Animals can be domesticated or hunted, plants harvested and brewed, and artifacts crafted that become part of the world’s mythology. Failure is often framed as part of the experience, as collapsing fortresses leave ruins that can be revisited in future playthroughs.The 2022 release introduced significant graphical updates, replacing ASCII characters with detailed tilesets and sprite-based representations of dwarves, creatures, and environments. The interface was redesigned for accessibility with mouse support and clearer menus, while the underlying simulation and mechanics remain faithful to the original version.

column1: Ender Magnolia: Bloom in the Mist

column3: Horizon II: Forbidden West is a single-player open-world action role-playing game. The story continues the journey of Aloy, a hunter living in a post-apocalyptic world where remnants of humanity survive alongside dangerous animal-like machines. After uncovering a new threat tied to a spreading blight and malfunctioning machines, she must travel into the Forbidden West, a frontier of diverse landscapes and tribes, in search of the technology that can preserve life on Earth. Along the way, she encounters new allies, rival clans, and increasingly powerful machines.Gameplay builds on the systems of Horizon: Zero Dawn, combining exploration, combat, and crafting. The player navigates varied environments including forests, deserts, mountains, and underwater areas. Aloy uses a focus device to scan surroundings, revealing enemy weaknesses and environmental points of interest. Combat relies on ranged weapons such as bows, slings, and spike throwers, as well as close-range melee strikes with a spear. Enemy machines feature destructible components, which can be targeted to disable weapons, harvest resources, or expose vulnerabilities.Progression is tied to a skill tree divided into multiple playstyles, such as hunting, melee combat, machine overrides, or stealth. Players earn experience points by completing quests, defeating machines, and exploring, which unlock new abilities. Equipment can be upgraded at workbenches using materials gathered from machines and the environment. Traps, potions, and ammunition types provide additional tactical options during encounters.Secondary systems include settlements where Aloy can trade, take side quests, or participate in activities such as hunting challenges. Dialogue choices occasionally allow the player to influence Aloy’s tone or response, though the overall story progression remains fixed. Machines can be overridden to serve as mounts or allies in combat, expanding traversal options across land and water. The game also introduces mini-games and diversions, such as Strike, a collectible board game that uses machine figurines in tactical matches. Exploration is enhanced by swimming mechanics, glider use, and climbing improvements, allowing more vertical freedom than the previous entry.

column1: Indiana Jones and the Great Circle
column3: Indiana Jones and the Great Circle is a single-player first-person action game. Set in 1937 between the films Raiders of the Lost Ark and The Last Crusade, the story follows archaeologist Indiana Jones as he uncovers a conspiracy centered on the concept of the Great Circle, a mysterious pattern connecting sacred sites across the world. When Nazis and rival archaeologists pursue artifacts tied to this enigma, Indy becomes entangled in a race against time, traveling from the halls of the Vatican to remote Himalayan mountains in search of answers. The player assumes his role directly, using exploration, investigation, and combat to unravel the mystery while confronting enemies who seek to exploit the discovery.Gameplay is presented primarily from a first-person perspective, blending traversal, puzzle-solving, and combat. Players navigate archaeological sites, tombs, and urban locations using climbing, rope swinging, stealth, and environmental interaction to advance. Indy’s iconic whip functions as a versatile tool: it can be used to swing across gaps, disarm opponents, or solve environmental puzzles that block progress. Traditional hand-to-hand combat and firearm use are also featured, allowing players to engage enemies through melee attacks, improvised weapons, and gunfights.Progression is structured around a series of interconnected missions, each offering different challenges such as stealth infiltration, action-driven encounters, or multi-step environmental puzzles. The whip and other tools gain importance as the player learns to combine them with the environment, for example triggering mechanisms, uncovering hidden passageways, or creating distractions. Puzzles draw on observation and experimentation, with solutions tied to symbols, artifacts, or architectural features.Combat encounters emphasize improvisation, with players encouraged to use the environment as a weapon. Objects in the surroundings can be picked up and thrown, enemies can be knocked into hazards, and fistfights replicate the rough physicality associated with the film character. Gunplay is more limited, providing ranged options when stealth or melee is not viable.The game includes cinematic set-pieces where scripted events and quick reactions move the story forward, such as chases, collapses, or confrontations with larger foes. These sequences are integrated into gameplay rather than presented as separate cutscenes, maintaining immersion while advancing the narrative. Exploration outside the main objectives often reveals collectible documents or hidden relics that expand the lore of the Great Circle.

Citizen Sleeper 2: Starward Vector is a single-player narrative-driven role-playing game. The story continues in the same universe as Citizen Sleeper, where the player takes the role of a Sleeper, an artificial body carrying a copied human mind. This Sleeper has escaped corporate ownership and now finds themself piloting a stolen ship in the Starward Belt, a lawless expanse at the edge of inhabited space. Together with a small crew gathered along the way, the player must survive on the margins, forge alliances, and search for meaning in a sector where factions, stations, and outlaws struggle for resources and control.Gameplay centers on the tabletop-inspired dice cycle system carried over from the first game. Each cycle, the player rolls a pool of dice representing available actions and assigns them to tasks across stations, ships, and encounters. Higher values increase chances of success in dangerous work, while lower values may still be useful for routine labor or dialogue-driven challenges. This structure governs how the Sleeper explores locations, completes contracts, and pushes forward story threads, balancing risk against survival needs.Progression is tied to managing both the Sleeper’s decaying synthetic body and the upkeep of their ship. Players must secure stabilizer doses to prevent breakdown while also maintaining the vessel’s systems through repairs and upgrades. Ship modules can be expanded to add workstations, living quarters, or specialized equipment that open new opportunities during voyages. Running a ship also means managing fuel, supplies, and crew well-being, as neglecting any element can undermine long-term survival.Crew recruitment and relationships are central to advancement. Each companion comes with skills, backstory, and personal quests that intersect with the larger political and social struggles of the Belt. Crew members influence which contracts are available and how events unfold, while also bringing new abilities to the dice system. Their loyalty and morale can shift depending on the player’s choices, creating branching paths for missions and endings.Dialogue remains a core feature, with branching narrative choices tied closely to character relationships and faction outcomes. Unlike traditional morality systems, outcomes reflect pragmatic survival in a hostile world rather than binary good or evil paths. Story arcs are designed to be modular, allowing the player to pursue threads in different orders, with each playthrough producing a different sequence of alliances and consequences.

Mario + Rabbids: Sparks of Hope is a single-player tactical role-playing game. The story begins when a cosmic entity known as Cursa spreads dark matter corruption, threatening the galaxy and consuming the energy of creatures called Sparks. Mario, his allies, and the Rabbids are drawn into this conflict after their world is invaded. The player controls this unlikely band of heroes as they travel between planets, rescue Sparks, and stop Cursa’s forces from spreading destruction across multiple worlds.Gameplay is structured around tactical, turn-based battles that combine elements of strategy and free movement. Unlike the previous grid-based system, characters now move within circular zones that allow them to dash into enemies, reposition for cover, or team-jump with an ally to reach new areas. Combat mixes direct weapon fire, character abilities, and Spark powers that add elemental effects such as fire, shock, or frost. Enemies vary in type and behavior, requiring different approaches and positioning to defeat.Progression comes from completing battles, solving planetary challenges, and recruiting Sparks. Each hero has a distinct set of weapons and abilities that can be upgraded, while Sparks can be equipped to further customize playstyles. Players earn experience, coins, and skill prisms that can be invested into ability trees, enhancing mobility, attack strength, or defensive options.Outside of battles, the player explores open planetary environments. These worlds contain side quests, puzzles, hidden treasures, and optional combat encounters that provide resources and new Sparks. Exploration is more free-form than in the previous game, with less linear overworld paths and more environmental interaction.

Inscryption is a single-player deckbuilding and narrative-driven puzzle strategy game. The story begins with the player trapped in a dark cabin, forced to play a mysterious card game overseen by an enigmatic figure named Leshy. Progression through the game requires winning card battles while uncovering hidden secrets in the cabin. The player takes on the role of an unnamed challenger, gradually piecing together the nature of the card game, the cabin itself, and the larger mystery tied to the world outside.Core gameplay centers on tactical card battles across a 3x4 grid. Players summon creatures using various resources: blood, bones, or energy, each gained through different mechanics such as sacrificing existing cards or having creatures perish in battle. Victory is determined by dealing damage on the opponent’s side of the scale, with damage values represented visually on a balance. Loss occurs when the opponent tips the scale in their favor. Different card types and unique sigils introduce abilities like flight, instant kills, or additional summons, creating synergies and strategic planning opportunities.Between battles, exploration allows interaction with objects in the cabin and participation in roguelike map progression. Each run places the player along a branching path where encounters include combat, campfires to strengthen cards, traders for new cards, or events that alter the deck. Defeat typically results in restarting, though the deck and options can change with every attempt. Deckbuilding is incremental, encouraging experimentation with combinations of creatures and abilities.Beyond card battles, the game includes escape-room style puzzles inside the cabin. Solving locked boxes, safes, and other hidden mechanisms grants new cards or items that affect gameplay. These puzzles also expand the narrative, hinting at the nature of the cabin’s master and the layered reality surrounding the card game.Over time, Inscryption shifts into new formats that change both the card game rules and the narrative perspective. Additional chapters introduce different card systems, including digital card interfaces, expanded resource management, and meta-narrative elements that reshape the meaning of earlier gameplay.

1000xRESIST is a single-player narrative-driven adventure game. Set 1,000 years in the future, the story follows a society of human clones who live under the rule of the Allmother, a revered figure believed to have saved humanity from extinction. Players take the role of a clone known as Watcher, whose task is to experience and preserve memories that define their society. As doubts about the truth of the Allmother’s legacy begin to surface, the protagonist explores shifting timelines and realities to uncover hidden truths about identity, history, and survival.Gameplay alternates between third-person exploration and first-person memory sequences. The player navigates hubs and environments within the enclosed society, interacting with characters and uncovering details of the clone hierarchy. During memory dives, the perspective shifts to controlled narrative vignettes where the player relives past events through the eyes of others, experiencing both scripted sequences and sections where limited player agency influences perspective and pacing. The player transitions between futuristic facilities, memory spaces, and surreal environments, each presenting changes in visual and narrative framing.Progression relies on advancing through chapters tied to memories and encounters. Puzzles are light and narrative-driven, often requiring the player to observe, connect details, or follow prompts to continue through story segments. The game’s structure emphasizes atmosphere and storytelling over traditional combat or survival mechanics, with no resource management or direct action systems.Dialogue and choice play a role in how the player interprets events. While the overall story follows a fixed arc, branching conversations and different responses affect character interactions and the player’s understanding of the world. These decisions influence tone rather than branching into divergent gameplay paths, keeping the focus on narrative delivery.

Returnal is a roguelike action game with a dark sci-fi theme. It is set on the planet Atropos where the ASTRA Corporation explorer Selene Vassos crash lands her space ship Helios, disobeying orders as she chases after a signal she dubs White Shadow. The hostile planet has a dense environment as she looks for a way back. After dying once Selene discovers she is resurrected right away and is stuck in a time loop, waking up near the ship and having to start over all again.The game is played from a behind view as Selene traverses the environments and fights extraterrestrial entities. It consists of six biomes, each with a distinct biotechnological theme, environment and enemies. Death is permanent and an intended part of the gameplay, as the knowledge from runs is used to push deeper into the alien world. There are also several story fragments at certain points, through animated cut-scenes or interactive sequences played from a first-person view with elements of horror and mystery. Each run takes place in a unique take on the biome with reshuffled rooms, randomized enemies and items. There are also several metroidvania elements as Selene gradually gets access to new abilities, one of the few game elements that are carried over between runs.Exploring a biome eventually leads to a boss encounter where multi-tier fights borrow heavily from bullet hell games, a developer trademark, as Selene has to dodge a large number of projectiles. She has swift movement that incorporates running, jumping, dashing with a brief window of invincibility, a powerful melee attack and a single ranged weapon. There are several weapons in the game, but only one can be carried at a time. They include a pistol, a blaster and a shotgun, but also exotic types such as the Hollowseeker, an Electropylon Launcher, a Rotgland Lobber, a Pyroshell Caster, a Thermogenic Launcher and more, each with unique projectile types, an alternative fire mode with cooldown and an active reload system that punishes fumbling. A biome consists of connected rooms that feature arena-like combat against diverse and often deadly enemies in a large numbers, exploration with platforms, ledges and tunnels, and a small amount of puzzle-solving, especially for secrets and special items.There is a currency based around obolites, left behind by destroyed enemies, to fabricate consumable items and augmentations that are lost when Selene dies. This involves a lot of risk and reward as there are also parasites with both positive and negative elements, health items that are often maligned causing negative effects, and vaults (chests) that follow the same principle. Through weapon proficiency better weapons are found and enemies are level matched against them. Even the same weapons are often unique through different statistics, and traits that are unlocked gradually and then become permanent in the item pool, adding effects such as critical hits, stagger or additional attacks. Ammo is always unlimited. Risk and reward also plays a role in traversal, as many rooms and certain encounters are optional, but provide powerful rewards when the risk is taken. The player often has to choose how much time to invest in a run as well, opting to stock up on augmentations, second chances and powerful consumables, or going through biomes quickly to reach a boss fast, but often underpowered.While almost all progress is lost when dead, gradually a few optional shortcuts open up. The few elements that are carried over between runs are unlocked items that become part of the randomised pool, quicker access to certain biomes, weapon traits, certain abilities, and ether as a permanent currency. Ether is used to unlock items, avenge the ghosts of other players in powerful enemy encounters and participate in daily challenges. There is also a cooperative online mode (added post launch) that is accessed from inside a biome. Tower of Sisyphus is an endless mode set in a separate location introducing new enemies, weapons, items and story fragments.

Kirby and the Forgotten Land is a single-player and cooperative 3D platform game. The story begins when Kirby is swept away from Dream Land into a mysterious, abandoned world where the structures of a lost civilization have been overtaken by nature. Soon after arriving, Kirby discovers that Waddle Dees are being captured by the Beast Pack, a group of animal-like enemies that dominate this strange place. With the help of a new companion named Elfilin, Kirby sets out to rescue the Waddle Dees and uncover the secrets of the forgotten land.Gameplay takes place across fully 3D stages, each containing platforming challenges, combat encounters, and hidden objectives. Kirby retains his signature ability to inhale enemies and copy their powers, allowing him to wield familiar abilities such as Sword, Fire, and Hammer, along with new ones like Drill and Ranger. Each copy ability can be upgraded between missions to unlock stronger attacks and altered move sets.In addition to copy abilities, Kirby can use “Mouthful Mode”, which allows him to inhale large objects that cannot be swallowed. This temporarily transforms him into unusual forms, such as a car, vending machine, or glider, each granting unique movement or combat options. These transformations are integrated into both traversal and puzzle-solving, offering variety across the stages.Progression is tied to rescuing Waddle Dees hidden in each level. Collected Waddle Dees return to Waddle Dee Town, which gradually expands with shops, side activities, and useful facilities. The number of Waddle Dees freed also determines access to later areas and boss encounters, linking exploration to advancement.The game supports drop-in cooperative play, allowing a second player to control Bandana Waddle Dee. In co-op, Kirby retains all copy and transformation powers while the partner uses a spear-based moveset. Coordination between players can make combat and exploration more efficient, though levels are balanced to remain fully playable solo.Secondary systems include collectible figures that can be found in stages or purchased with coins at capsule machines. These provide lore and information about characters, enemies, and items from the game. Mini-games such as fishing, serving food at the Waddle Dee Café, and timed delivery challenges add diversions within Waddle Dee Town. A Colosseum arena allows players to fight through waves of enemies and bosses for rewards, offering an additional test of skill outside the main adventure.

Cocoon is a single-player puzzle game. The game begins with the player controlling a small insect-like creature emerging in a barren desert. With no spoken dialogue or text, the setting and objectives are conveyed entirely through visuals and environmental cues. The protagonist journeys across alien landscapes filled with mysterious technology, shifting ecosystems, and monumental structures. The central goal is to uncover the secrets of interconnected worlds contained within glowing orbs, each harboring its own rules and environments.Gameplay focuses on exploration and puzzle-solving. The player carries orbs that function as both tools and entire self-contained worlds. Placing an orb in specific devices opens pathways or triggers mechanisms, while entering the orb transports the player into its miniature world. This creates layers of puzzles that span across dimensions, where manipulating one orb may alter the state of another. Progression requires learning the unique logic of each orb, combining them, and moving fluidly between worlds to solve increasingly complex challenges.Each orb introduces its own properties. One may grant access to hidden bridges, another could reveal light-sensitive platforms, while another alters gravity or mobility. These mechanics build upon one another, forcing the player to think spatially and track cause-and-effect across several interconnected puzzles. Combat is minimal but present in the form of large biomechanical guardians. These encounters play out as environmental boss puzzles, where survival depends on using the available tools and arena features rather than traditional fighting.

Neva is a single-player action puzzle platformer game. The story follows Alba, a young woman whose world is threatened by corruption spreading across the land. After surviving a devastating attack, she forms a bond with a wolf cub born in the chaos. As the two travel together through forests, ruins, and desolate valleys, Alba and the wolf must learn to rely on each other in order to endure. The narrative unfolds without spoken dialogue, instead using animation, atmosphere, and symbolism to convey Alba’s journey of survival, grief, and companionship.Gameplay combines exploration with light combat and puzzle-solving. Players guide Alba through side-scrolling environments, climbing, running, and navigating obstacles while also engaging corrupted creatures that block the way. Combat is melee-based, with Alba wielding a sword that can be chained into simple combos or used defensively against hostile enemies. The wolf serves as both a partner and a mechanic in traversal, capable of interacting with the environment to activate platforms or reach inaccessible areas.Progression is structured through Alba’s evolving bond with the wolf. As the companion grows, it develops new abilities that expand traversal and puzzle-solving options, such as pushing objects, creating pathways, or distracting enemies during combat encounters. These abilities are introduced gradually, requiring the player to adapt and use teamwork to advance. Enemy encounters are not focused on complex systems but instead on managing timing and using the environment strategically. Mistakes or defeats are handled with quick resets, keeping the experience fluid and minimizing mechanical barriers to storytelling.

Huntdown is a single-player and cooperative 2D run-and-gun shooter. Set in a dystopian future where organized crime controls the streets, players take on the role of bounty hunters contracted to dismantle violent gangs that rule the city. Each gang dominates its own territory, and missions task the player with eliminating their bosses while dealing with heavily armed thugs, machines, and criminal infrastructure along the way.Missions are structured as side-scrolling stages that combine fast-paced shooting with cover mechanics. Players can run, crouch, slide, and take cover behind objects to avoid enemy fire. Weapons are varied and include pistols, machine guns, shotguns, grenades, and more exotic firearms. Ammunition is limited, encouraging players to swap weapons frequently by picking them up from defeated enemies or scattered caches.The central challenge of each mission is a boss encounter at the end of the stage. These encounters feature distinct attack patterns and require players to learn behaviors and weak points while managing waves of backup enemies. Levels are designed to be short but intense, focusing on tight arenas filled with destructible cover and hazards. Scoring is based on completion time, enemies defeated, and collection of loot dropped by gang members, rewarding efficient play.Progression is linear, with new stages unlocked after each boss is defeated. At the start, players can select from three bounty hunters: Anna Conda, a former commando armed with an SMG; John Sawyer, a veteran carrying a pump-action shotgun; and Mow Man, a masked vigilante equipped with throwing axes. Their differing primary weapons subtly influence how combat unfolds, offering replay value across the campaign.Two-player local co-op allows friends drop-in and tackle missions together, sharing pickups and coordinating attacks. Stages also encourage replay by tracking scores, completion times, and collectible briefcases hidden in each level. There are no branching storylines or morality choices, and progression remains consistent between solo and co-op sessions.

Final Fantasy VI (also released as Final Fantasy VI Pixel Remaster) is a single-player role-playing game. It takes place in a world where the remnants of ancient magic clash with the power of technology. The story follows Terra Branford, a young woman born with mysterious powers linked to the long-lost art of magic. After escaping the control of an oppressive empire, Terra joins a growing resistance movement known as the Returners. As the empire’s ambitions threaten to unbalance the world, the narrative expands to include a large ensemble cast of allies, each with their own backstories, motivations, and personal quests that intertwine across the fate of a decaying civilization.The game’s structure alternates between linear story-driven segments and open-world exploration. Players navigate towns, dungeons, and world maps while recruiting new characters and managing an evolving party. The adventure unfolds through cinematic sequences, branching character arcs, and major shifts in setting and tone, including a world-altering event midway through the game that reshapes both narrative direction and exploration.Combat uses the Active Time Battle (ATB) system, where time continuously flows and each character’s turn becomes available after their action gauge fills. Every party member has a unique command ability that defines their combat role. For example, Locke can steal items from enemies, Sabin executes martial arts techniques through directional inputs, Edgar deploys mechanical tools, and Celes casts magic through a defensive Runic command. Players must manage health, magic points, and tactical turn order to balance offense and defense during encounters.Progression centers on character development through equipment, levels, and the use of Espers, magical entities that teach spells and enhance statistics. Equipping an Esper grants access to new magic as characters gain experience, allowing for individualized skill builds. Espers can also be summoned temporarily in battle to unleash powerful elemental attacks. Items, weapons, and relics modify abilities and attributes, enabling custom strategies for different party compositions.Outside of battle, the player can interact with a wide range of optional content and mini-games. Notable examples include the coliseum, where items are wagered for combat rewards, and the iconic opera sequence, which blends gameplay with narrative performance. Exploration is encouraged through hidden side quests and recruitable optional characters, some of whom contribute to alternate endings or unique story scenes.This version updates the original with redrawn 2D visuals, an orchestrated soundtrack, and revised typography. Quality-of-life enhancements include an autosave function, encounter rate adjustments, and improved menus for managing Espers, inventory, and abilities. Optional modifiers allow for adjusted experience gain and faster battles.

Total War: Warhammer III is a single-player and multiplayer strategy game that combines turn-based empire management with real-time tactical battles. The story is set in the Warhammer universe and centers on the struggle for control of Ursun, the Bear God of Kislev, whose imprisonment creates a power vacuum between mortal factions and the four Chaos Gods. Players can lead nations such as Kislev, Grand Cathay, or one of the Daemonic legions, each pursuing their own objectives in a conflict that spans both the mortal world and the Realms of Chaos.The campaign map plays out in a turn-based format where the player manages settlements, builds infrastructure, raises armies, and negotiates with rival factions. Armies move across provinces to expand territory and confront enemies, with each region providing resources, strategic chokepoints, or diplomatic leverage. Victory conditions vary between factions, with some requiring dominance over rival nations and others demanding progress through the Chaos Realms to secure Ursun’s fate.When armies clash, the game shifts into real-time battles. Players command large formations of infantry, cavalry, artillery, and monsters, maneuvering them across varied terrain to outflank opponents and exploit weaknesses. Unit abilities reflect their lore origins, from Cathay’s harmony-based synergy to the Chaos factions’ daemonic powers. Hero characters and lords provide leadership bonuses and magical spells that can alter the outcome of engagements, while morale and fatigue systems influence the effectiveness of troops in prolonged combat.Progression is tied to both empire-building and character development. Generals and heroes gain experience and can be customized through skill trees that unlock new powers or improve army efficiency. Factions maintain unique mechanics: Kislev balances the competing influences of its religious and political leaders, Grand Cathay relies on trade and the harmony between Yin and Yang, and the Daemon factions embody the themes of their patron gods, each with distinct campaign rules and battle tactics. These asymmetrical designs create different strategic challenges depending on the chosen faction.Secondary systems expand the scope of play. Diplomacy allows alliances, trade agreements, and treaties, but AI rivals may be influenced by cultural aversion or alignment to Chaos. Random events, dilemmas, and scripted story missions add narrative variety across campaigns. Multiplayer includes competitive battles as well as cooperative campaigns where players can pursue parallel or conflicting goals. Mod support is available on PC versions, adding further customization for players.The game is designed to integrate with its predecessors in the trilogy, Total War: Warhammer and Total War: Warhammer II. Owners of earlier titles can access their factions in the combined “Immortal Empires” campaign, a grand-scale map that merges all three games into one extended experience.

Xenoblade Chronicles: Definitive Edition is a remake of the original Xenoblade Chronicles with updated graphics and a somewhat different art style. Changes in content are minimal, and mostly consist of quality of life features such as difficulty settings, an improved quest tracker, and fashion gear. New content includes a time trials mode and a handful of new equipment sets.Definitive Edition also includes a brand-new epilogue chapter, Future Connected, which can be accessed at any time independent of progress in the main game. One year after the events of the original game, Shulk and Melia set off for the imperial city of Alcamoth, of which the latter is crown princess. However, a malevolent, incorporeal being called the Fog King has appeared in the city from a rift in space-time and driven the residents to the Bionis' Shoulder. Tensions between the survivors have fractured their community, leaving them with little hope of ever returning to their homeland. Melia takes it upon herself to reunite her people and retake the capital, and in the process prove her worth as heir to the throne.Shulk and Melia are joined in their quest by a pair of Nopon named Nene and Kino, children of Riki who wish to follow in their father's footsteps and become heroes. The party are also able to recruit the Ponspectors, a Nopon survey crew who offer their assistance in battle. In addition to randomly jumping in to use special skills, the Ponspectors can combine their power to launch an all-out attack against the enemy. Other mechanics from the main game have been streamlined or removed to better fit the shorter campaign.

The Talos Principle: Reawakened is a single-player first-person puzzle game. This title is a comprehensive remaster of the original 2014 game, The Talos Principle, rebuilt in Unreal Engine 5 and released in 2025. It retains the foundational narrative and puzzle structures while introducing significantly upgraded visuals (enhanced lighting, richer environmental detail, and ray tracing effects) alongside expanded content and modernized gameplay features. The package includes the remastered Road to Gehenna expansion and adds an entirely new chapter, In the Beginning, which explores the early origins of the Simulation through the perspective of its original human architects. Additionally, it introduces a developer commentary mode, a full puzzle editor for community creations, and a suite of quality-of-life and accessibility improvements.The story is set in a far-future world where humanity has vanished and robots carry the legacy of human culture. Players take the role of a newly awakened artificial being exploring a vast landscape filled with ancient ruins, advanced technology, and philosophical questions about consciousness and free will. Guided and challenged by mysterious voices and texts scattered throughout the world, the protagonist must uncover the truth behind the society of machines, its origins, and its uncertain future.Gameplay revolves around solving environmental puzzles across interconnected regions. Each puzzle chamber presents mechanical devices such as jammers, connectors, and other tools that interact with gates, energy fields, and turrets. Players must experiment with spatial reasoning and timing to create solutions that allow access to sigils or keys required for progression. The structure is open-ended, with multiple puzzle hubs available at once, letting players choose which challenges to attempt in any order.Puzzles frequently combine multiple systems, requiring the player to manipulate light beams, redirect energy, and activate pressure plates while avoiding hazards. Some challenges rely on sequencing actions correctly, while others demand the creation of elaborate multi-step solutions using limited tools. As in earlier entries, exploration and experimentation are emphasized, and players can often find more than one valid approach to a problem.Progression is tied to collecting sigils and other items from puzzle chambers. These unlock new areas and mechanics, gradually raising the complexity of challenges. Certain puzzles also introduce optional golden sigils, stars, and hidden collectibles for players seeking more difficult tasks. The game includes larger-scale “mega puzzles” that integrate mechanics across multiple chambers, rewarding persistence and long-term problem solving.Outside of puzzles, players navigate expansive hub environments that encourage exploration. These spaces contain terminals with texts, interactive structures, and philosophical dialogues that develop the game’s narrative. Conversations with other AI characters introduce moral and existential debates, and choices made in these interactions affect how the story unfolds and which ending paths are available.

Neon White is a single-player first-person action platform game. The story centers on a group of assassins, called Neons, who are plucked from the underworld and brought to Heaven to compete in trials against demons. The protagonist, known as White, awakens without clear memory of his past but must participate in these contests, with the promise of permanent residence in Heaven granted to the victor. Along the way, White encounters other Neons who seem to share a connection with him, and interactions gradually reveal pieces of his forgotten history.Gameplay is structured around short, time-based levels where the goal is to eliminate all demons and reach the exit as quickly as possible. Players navigate stages in first person, using fluid movement abilities such as jumping, double-jumping, and dashing. Speed is the primary focus, with each stage designed for rapid completion, encouraging repeated attempts to discover shortcuts and optimize routes.Weapons are acquired through Soul Cards, which serve as both firearms and movement tools. Each card corresponds to a weapon type, such as pistols, rifles, or shotguns, but also has a discard ability that provides a mobility skill like a dash, stomp, or bomb jump. Since cards vanish when discarded, players must balance offensive use with traversal needs. Level design frequently requires combining attacks and movement abilities, forcing quick decision-making to maintain momentum.Completion times are ranked, with bronze, silver, gold, and ace medals awarded based on speed. Faster ranks unlock leaderboards and developer “insight” times, which highlight efficient strategies. Replayability is emphasized, as levels are designed with multiple possible paths that reward experimentation.Outside of stages, the player can interact with other Neons through dialogue sequences. These segments expand on story details and allow White to build relationships with supporting characters by giving them gifts collected during missions. Building affinity unlocks additional narrative scenes and side content. Dialogue is structured in a visual novel style, presented between action segments.

Mullet MadJack is a single-player first-person roguelike shooter. The story takes place in a neon-lit cyberpunk future where society is controlled by media-obsessed mega-corporations. The player assumes the role of MadJack, a mercenary with a cybernetic mullet who must climb a corporate tower to rescue an abducted influencer. His survival depends on maintaining a constant feed of adrenaline through violent combat: every sixty seconds, he must kill an enemy to reset a countdown timer or risk instant death.Combat is fast-paced and heavily focused on chaining kills. MadJack wields a variety of weapons such as pistols, shotguns, and energy arms, each with distinct firing patterns and reload speeds. Defeated enemies drop weapons and temporary power-ups, encouraging players to keep moving and swap armaments often. In addition to firearms, melee strikes and finishing moves allow for close-quarters takedowns, creating a blend of ranged and hand-to-hand combat that keeps the timer replenished.The game is structured around procedurally generated floors of the tower. Each level presents compact arenas filled with enemies, traps, and environmental hazards. Players must clear rooms quickly while navigating vertical layouts and branching paths. As in many roguelikes, death is permanent, sending the player back to the start, but experience and familiarity with layouts contribute to faster progress over repeated runs.Progression is tied to upgrades earned between stages. Completing floors rewards currency that can be invested into permanent enhancements, including health boosts, weapon modifiers, and special abilities. Temporary upgrades, called buffs, can also be collected during runs, granting short-lived advantages such as explosive rounds or improved movement speed. These systems encourage experimentation with different builds and playstyles while maintaining the high-risk, high-speed loop.Visual design takes inspiration from late-20th-century anime and arcade shooters, with bold outlines, exaggerated effects, and a saturated color palette. The soundtrack uses fast electronic beats to reinforce the constant pressure of the timer.

Frostpunk 2 is a single-player city-building and survival strategy game. The story is set thirty years after the apocalyptic blizzard that defined the fate of humanity in the original Frostpunk. The age of coal has ended, and oil is now seen as the key to survival. Players take the role of the Steward, the leader of a growing city that has endured decades of winter, tasked with managing resources, maintaining order, and guiding society through political conflicts as the world inches closer to collapse.The central gameplay loop revolves around expanding and managing a city built around massive generators that protect the population from the endless cold. Unlike its predecessor, the focus is not only on day-to-day survival but also on long-term planning, with oil extraction and refinement becoming the foundation of the city’s future. As leader, players must allocate resources, plan districts, and expand infrastructure while contending with the ever-present threat of hunger, disease, and freezing temperatures.Survival depends on difficult moral and political choices. Systems of governance allow players to enact new laws that shape the city’s direction, from labor policies and social support to security measures and industrial priorities. Each decision can stabilize or destabilize the community, and political factions form based on ideology, pushing for survival at any cost or demanding humane treatment even in dire conditions. Players must balance competing visions for the future to prevent civil unrest or outright collapse.The game introduces a Council system, where factions debate policies and can shift power dynamics depending on the player’s actions. These assemblies determine the success or failure of laws, and alliances or betrayals within the Council can change the course of the city’s development. The system transforms governance into a strategic layer where diplomacy, persuasion, or authoritarian enforcement are viable paths.Secondary features include branching narrative arcs tied to ideology, with multiple endings depending on how the player handles disputes over resources, survival strategies, and morality. Exploration of the frozen world remains, with expeditions venturing outside the city walls to locate survivors, gather scarce resources, or expand influence. Unlike the first game, the emphasis is on long-term ideological survival rather than short-term crises, and choices accumulate into larger societal consequences.

Quake is an updated and remastered compilation release of id Software's original Quake for the occasion of its 25th anniversary. It includes:For all platforms except Windows, this is the first release of the game.The game also includes community-curated and updated mods as free downloads through their Bethesda.net service (online account and registration required), and includes a port of the Nintendo 64 Quake campaign on launch. The PC version is open to all mods, for the console versions the selection is curated. It features maps that have been slightly altered from the original PC campaign, a special screen filter effect, plus the original soundtrack composed for that release.The game's multiplayer has also been overhauled, allowing for four player same-screen co-op gameplay or arena versus modes, four player online co-op, or up to eight players versus online through Bethesda.net, which also allows for crossplay between the different platforms. Steam releases of the game also include Quake v1.09, which can be used to play older game campaigns and mods, as well as classic LAN multiplayer.This version of the game supports additional technical improvements for compatible platforms, such as widescreen support, 4K resolution, enhanced models, dynamic lighting, anti-aliasing, depth of field, and more graphical enhancements. A later released free update for the Xbox Series and PlayStation 5 versions introduces 4K/120fps.

column1: Star Ocean: The Second Story R
column3: Star Ocean: The Second Story R is a single-player action role-playing game. It is an enhanced remake of Star Ocean: The Second Story and its expanded version Star Ocean: Second Evolution, rebuilt with 2.5D graphics that merge sprite-based characters with fully rendered 3D environments. This edition includes orchestrated and original soundtrack options, new voice acting for both protagonists and supporting cast, and quality-of-life adjustments such as updated battle mechanics, streamlined menus, and improved navigation. The remake also introduces new art direction, redrawn character portraits, and modern visual effects.The story follows Claude C. Kenny, a young ensign from the Earth Federation, and Rena Lanford, a girl from the underdeveloped planet Expel who possesses mysterious powers. After Claude is transported to Expel through ancient technology, he and Rena become embroiled in a conflict between nations and an otherworldly threat. The narrative branches depending on whether the player chooses Claude or Rena as the main protagonist, each perspective shaping relationships and character interactions.The adventure unfolds through exploration of towns, dungeons, and a world map, where the party recruits companions and uncovers the unfolding plot. Character interactions influence “private actions,” optional story events that alter relationships and affect which of the multiple endings are unlocked.Combat takes place in real time on a battlefield where up to four party members engage enemies. The player directly controls one character, issuing commands and chaining skills, while AI guides allies. Abilities are mapped to buttons for quick access, and each character specializes in unique weapon types and techniques. Skills and symbology (the game’s magic system) provide offensive and defensive options, while tactical positioning remains important to avoid enemy strikes and exploit weaknesses.Progression is tied to leveling up through combat and earning Skill Points, which can be invested into categories such as combat techniques, symbology, crafting, or passive bonuses. Developing skills opens up new abilities, improves statistics, and enables item creation. This system allows for a wide range of customization. Equipment upgrades through weapons and armor are also possible.Dialogue and private actions play a key role in shaping party dynamics. Relationship values influence which of the more than 90 possible character endings appear, giving the narrative a personalized conclusion based on player decisions. The affinity system also affects battle bonuses and certain story scenes, creating a link between narrative choice and gameplay results.

This remastered release of the first three Mass Effect games includes the following content:The release is singleplayer-only, and the multiplayer features of Mass Effect 3 are not included; to compensate for this, the requirements for the different endings in the game have been reworked so players can still receive any of them. Also, due to the loss of its source code, Mass Effect: Pinnacle Station is also absent.The visuals have received a significant update despite the games using Unreal Engine 3 like their original versions, with the addition of a photo mode, native 21:9 resolution options, and DirectX 11 support. The character creation menu in all games is now based on the one from ME3, and many of the designs of characters, objects and locations were backported from that game to the other two as well. All three games received a balancing pass, most notably the Mako from ME1, as well as interface tweaks, the availability of all difficulty levels from the start, and an optional new leveling system in ME1. Finally, many bug fixes are implemented, some of which fix issues with importing decisions from one game to another via savegame files.The games are accessed from a unified launcher by default, but can be started individually. The three games are otherwise separate, and can be installed separately from each other on consoles, but only the whole compilation can be installed on Windows.

column1: AI: The Somnium Files - nirvanA Initiative
column3: AI: The Somnium Files – nirvanA Initiative is a single-player adventure game. The story follows two investigators from the Advanced Brain Investigation Squad, Mizuki Okiura and Ryuki Kuruto, who are tasked with solving the Half Body serial killings. Victims are found cut in half, with the second half of their bodies appearing six years later in seemingly impossible circumstances. The game’s narrative alternates between two timelines, as the player uncovers how the murders are connected and what links them to a wider conspiracy known as Nirvana.The game is structured as a mix of storytelling, exploration sequences, and interactive investigation segments. In dialogue and story scenes, players make choices that can influence the direction of events, unlocking different branches that lead to multiple possible outcomes. Investigations take place in real-world environments, where evidence is gathered, suspects are questioned, and small puzzles may be solved to push the case forward.A major gameplay system is the Somnium mechanic, where the protagonists use an AI companion housed in a prosthetic eye to enter the dreamscapes of witnesses or suspects. In these dream environments, time is limited and every action consumes a portion of a countdown timer. Players must interact with distorted objects and overcome abstract logic puzzles to uncover hidden memories or truths that cannot be accessed through normal questioning. Successfully completing a Somnium sequence reveals new leads or branches in the investigation.Combat does not feature prominently, but tense quick-time events and interactive sequences are used during certain story moments. Progression is instead tied to information gathering and branching routes, with a flowchart system allowing players to revisit earlier points in the story to explore alternate paths. Completing multiple routes is required to understand the full scope of the murder mystery.

Monster Hunter: Rise is a action role-playing game and the sixth mainline installment in the Monster Hunter series. The game takes place in a world known as the "New World," where players control a hunter who travels to different locations to hunt down large, dangerous creatures known as "Monsters." The goal of the game is to complete quests and hunt these monsters to gain resources and materials which can then be used to craft weapons and equipment to make the hunter stronger and better equipped to take on even tougher monsters.In terms of gameplay, it features both single player and multiplayer options. Players have access to a variety of weapons, each with unique playstyles and abilities, to use in battle against the monsters. The game also features a variety of mechanics such as traps, environmental interactions, and mounted combat, to help players bring down the monsters they are hunting. In addition to hunting, players can also collect resources, complete quests, and craft new equipment to enhance their abilities.Some of the distinctive features include the new "Wirebug" mechanic, which allows players to traverse the environment and attack monsters with increased mobility, and the new "Palamute" companion, a dog-like creature that can be used in battle to assist the player. The game also introduces a new setting, the "Sacred Land of the Lusha," as well as new monsters to hunt and new weapons to craft.

The seventh main installment (not counting Yakuza 0) in the cannon series of Yakuza (also known as Ryuu ga Gotoku) placed in the open-world modern Japan. Upgrading character's fighting skills, visiting fancy restaurants and fast food stores, and dealing with tons and tons of bad guys... the same recipe follows as with all the previous installments in the series. This time, however, is the first time that Sega changed the main protagonist which is no longer the Legendary Dragon of Dojima also known as Kazuma Kiryu.

Gran Turismo 7 is a single-player and multiplayer racing simulation game. The game places the player in the role of a driver and car collector who progresses through a wide range of events, licenses, and championships while building a personal garage of vehicles. Its structure mixes career-style progression with open-ended driving options, presenting both a narrative of advancement and a broad toolset for motorsport experimentation.The central mode is the GT Café, which organizes the player’s journey through themed "menu books" that set objectives such as collecting certain models or winning specific championships. Completing these unlocks new cars, tracks, and progression milestones. Beyond the Café, the World Map hub offers direct access to dealerships, tuning shops, license tests, and circuits. This structure reflects the traditional Gran Turismo series career format, combining guided progression with freedom of choice.Races simulate real-world motorsport rules. Vehicles vary from compact hatchbacks to high-performance race cars, each accurately modeled in terms of handling, weight, aerodynamics, and engine characteristics. Weather and time-of-day systems affect track conditions dynamically, requiring adjustments in strategy and driving style. Players compete against AI opponents or human drivers, with race outcomes influenced by both driving skill and car performance.Progression is tied to car acquisition and customization. Cars can be purchased from Brand Central, used dealerships, or earned as rewards, then tuned with parts that adjust power, handling, and efficiency. Vehicles can also be painted and visually modified with a livery editor. The player’s collection grows into a garage that can be revisited for performance upgrades or aesthetic changes, making car management a major component of the experience.Secondary systems expand beyond racing. License tests teach advanced driving techniques through scenario-based challenges, while missions provide unique race formats such as drag events or endurance runs. Music Rally adds arcade-style races set to timed songs. Online multiplayer includes both casual lobbies and structured Sport Mode races with matchmaking based on performance and driver conduct. Daily races and tournaments are also featured, encouraging long-term competitive play.The game emphasizes presentation and education as well as competition. The GT Café’s commentary provides historical context on car design and manufacturers, and Scapes mode allows players to stage detailed photo shoots of their vehicles across real-world backgrounds.Cross-platform play is supported between PlayStation 4 and PlayStation 5 versions, and progress can transfer between systems. The PS5 edition adds features such as advanced haptic feedback and faster loading, though the core structure remains identical across platforms.

Hitman III is the third and final game in the World of Assassination trilogy, a subseries of the main Hitman franchise, started with Hitman: The Complete First Season in 2016. This entry continues the large freedom in approach to control Agent 47 in his assassination missions. New elements introduced in this entry are security keypads, time limitations, and 47's camera/scanner. Shortcuts are a new element where for instance lowered ladders become persistent across attempts. There are no multiplayer modes: Sniper Assassin is single player and Ghost Mode is removed. The PS4 version has support for virtual reality, a first for the series.The missions bring the protagonist to six new locations: Berlin (Germany), Chongqing (China), Dubai, Dartmoor (UK), Mendoza (Argentina) and an epilogue set in the Carpathian Mountains (Romania). The ongoing story is continued and with more focus on it. At the start of the game the team of Agent 47 wants to extract information from Arthur Edward (the Constant) who has captured at the end of the previous game, with the ultimate goal to get closer to the secret society Providence Partners.For PC, PlayStation and Xbox players are able to manually carry over progress inside the same console/system family from Hitman 2 as well as from the first Hitman locations through the Legacy Pack (player profile, XP rank, location mastery levels, location mastery unlocks, challenge progress, challenge unlocks and Elusive Target suits/unlocks). For Stadia progress from the first two games is carried over automatically.This game also brings improvements to the previous two games. Owners can access the missions, locations and content of both previous games free of charge inside the same console/system family, bringing over both games entirely inside Hitman III free of charge. Unlocked items can be used across all three games and the graphics, animations and AI from the third game are brought over to the first two. Players who do not own the previous two games can buy them through Access Passes. This also applies to the Switch version for which this is the first release of the game for the platform. Owners of the PS4/Xbox One disc version receive a next-gen upgrade for their next-gen disc system free of charge.

Doom: The Dark Ages is a first-person shooter and be the eighth mainline entry in the Doom franchise. It serves as a prequel to the events of Doom (2016). The game marks a stylistic and mechanical shift for the series, blending the franchise's hallmark combat with medieval-inspired aesthetics and grounded, tactical gameplay.Unlike its immediate predecessors, Doom (2016) and Doom Eternal, which emphasized fast-paced, acrobatic movement and an aggressive flow of combat driven by double jumps, dashes, and environmental mobility, Doom: The Dark Ages adopts a slower, more deliberate approach. Combat in this title is centered around the concept of the Doom Slayer as an "iron tank," relying on heavy weaponry, shield-based mechanics, and enhanced melee capabilities. The game introduces a new core mechanic in the form of the Shield Saw, which allows for parrying, blocking, and offensive attacks with a single input. This shield also plays a role in both traversal and puzzle-solving, interacting with heated enemy armor and environmental objects in explosive ways. The Doom Slayer's arsenal includes new weapons such as the Skull Crusher, a gun that fires bone fragments, and a variety of melee options including a flail, gauntlet, and iron mace.The game places a renewed emphasis on narrative and world-building, expanding on the origins of the Doom Slayer and the lore of Argent D’Nur. Set during an ancient war between the Night Sentinels and the forces of Hell, the story features new characters including Kreed Maykr, Thira, and the antagonist Prince Ahzrak. Cutscenes and character-driven plot points are more prominent than in prior entries, offering a deeper exploration of motivations and internal conflict, particularly surrounding the Slayer’s struggle with external control through a device known as the Tether.Gameplay also features large, open-ended battlefields in contrast to the more confined arenas of previous titles. Enemies often spawn in formation or waves, encouraging strategic prioritization and varied approaches to combat. While the pace is more grounded, the intensity remains high. Tactical decision-making is reinforced through mechanics that reward precise timing and environmental awareness, such as executing parries to trigger area-of-effect reactions or managing cooldowns for melee attacks. There are also vehicle segments, including the piloting of a cybernetic dragon and a 30-story Atlan mech.Melee combat plays a more prominent role than in earlier installments, with three distinct melee weapons each possessing unique abilities and upgrade paths. Despite the heavier tone and slower pacing, the game retains Doom’s identity through its fluid weapon-switching system, lack of reloading, and emphasis on rhythmic, visceral combat. Classic elements such as keycard-based level progression and secret areas return.Level design features expansive environments including corrupted churches, haunted forests, shipyards, and Hellish wastelands. These areas combine Doom’s legacy of labyrinthine exploration with broader, almost battlefield-like layouts. Environmental interaction plays a larger role than before, with the shield used to manipulate terrain and mechanisms.

The game takes place in a performing arts school called the Univers Opera School. Since the game is an otome, players take on the role of Kisa Tachibana, a female who is forced to hide her identity in the all-men’s school. Tachibana hopes to re-kindle her passion for the theater by attending the opera school. Most of the game’s focus is on Tachibana’s participation in the final and most important show of the year, all the while trying to keep her identity a secret.Jack Jeanne focuses on Tachibana’s efforts to achieve what is called a “Quartz”, which is basically the top-ranking spot in every theater class. The game’s title derives upon the characters’ stage names; men who play a male role are referred to as Jack, while men who play a female role are referred to as Jeanne.The gameplay revolves around on two parts: the simulation aspects, in which you strengthen your bond with your classmates as the protagonist Tachibana and follows her story into the game; and the rhythm aspects, which are just the shows that the students perform while dancing in full 3D.

Pizza Tower is a single-player 2D platform game. The story follows Peppino Spaghetti, a nervous but determined pizza chef who learns that a massive tower threatens to destroy his pizzeria. To protect his livelihood, Peppino ventures into the tower, battling strange enemies and bizarre bosses across themed floors. His objective is to survive the tower’s hazards, defeat its guardians, and ultimately save his restaurant from destruction.Gameplay emphasizes speed, momentum, and aggressive movement. Levels are built with interconnected rooms and vertical structures, allowing players to dash, wall-run, slide, and shoulder-charge through enemies and obstacles. Unlike more deliberate platformers, progress relies on chaining movements together smoothly to maintain velocity and clear areas efficiently. The design rewards both exploration and quick reflexes, as players can either scour stages for secrets or focus on reaching the goal quickly.Each stage introduces enemies that can be defeated with Peppino’s melee attacks, grabs, and throws. Defeating enemies often clears paths or contributes to score multipliers, and combat is tightly integrated into traversal, with enemies positioned to challenge or enhance the player’s momentum. Certain hazards and mini-bosses interrupt the flow, requiring players to learn attack patterns while balancing platforming movement.Progression is tied to collecting points and treasures scattered throughout stages. At the midpoint of every level, the player must destroy a pillar to trigger an escape sequence. This reversal forces players to retrace their path under a strict time limit, with failure resulting in losing the level’s progress. The escape mechanic ensures every stage has a dual structure: exploration in the first half and frantic speedrunning in the second.Points are awarded for defeating enemies, chaining combos, and finding hidden collectibles such as toppings and secrets. Higher ranks require mastering the game’s momentum system and completing escape sequences efficiently. Rank ranges from simple clear grades to the highest “P-rank,” earned only by clearing the stage without breaking the action flow.

This remastered release of the 2010 Nintendo DS game Ghost Trick: Phantom Detective includes updated visuals and rearranged music, as well as a gallery of unlockable pieces of art and background music.

Streets of Rage 4 is a side-scrolling beat-'em-up, marking the first new mainline entry in the Streets of Rage series in 25 years. The game modernizes the classic formula with hand-drawn HD visuals, new combat mechanics, and a cooperative multiplayer.Gameplay retains the familiar left-to-right brawling action, with players fighting through 12 stages of enemies using combos, grapples, throws, and environmental weapons. Returning characters Axel Stone, Blaze Fielding, and Adam Hunter are joined by newcomers Cherry Hunter and Floyd Iraia, each with distinct fighting styles and mobility. Combat introduces a new health recovery mechanic that allows players to regain lost health from special attacks by chaining follow-up combos, as well as Star Moves, powerful super attacks fueled by collectible stars.Weapons such as pipes, knives, and bottles return, along with a new weapon catch feature that lets players throw and retrieve weapons mid-combat. Co-op play supports up to four players locally or two players online, with synergy-based combos and shared pickups encouraging teamwork.The campaign features five difficulty levels and additional modes such as Arcade Mode (single-life run), Boss Rush, and Battle Mode (PVP). Players can unlock retro pixel characters and soundtracks from the original trilogy. The game's soundtrack pays homage to the series' legacy of dance and electronic music.

The PlayStation 5 console was launched pre-loaded with the game Astro's Playroom starring the Astro Bot character first introduced in the 2018 PS4 PSVR title Astro Bot: Rescue Mission. This 3D platformer starts in a hub world called CPU Plaza from where four worlds can be explored: GPU Jungle, Cooling Springs, SSD Speedway and Memory Meadow, each based on PS5’s console components. In that way the game is used as an introduction to the features of the PS5, such as experiments with the adaptive triggers, the haptic features through DualSense or the 3D audio of the Tempest engine.Two other locations are also available from CPU Plaza: Network Speed Run with unlockable time trials and PlayStation Labo where all collectables are stored. Astro Bot can move around freely, jump, hover, punch objects and enemies, and charge a punch for a spin attack. Each world is split up in four levels each. Next to the regular levels there are some where Astro Bot has access to a power suit with new abilities, usually tied capabilities of the DualSense controller.The game contains many references to game franchises and the legacy of the PlayStation console. A fifth world with a final boss fight is unlocked after completing the first four.

Shin Megami Tensei V is a role-playing game that blends strategic combat, demon recruitment, and open-world exploration. Developed and published by Atlus for Nintendo Switch, it launched worldwide in November 2021 as the ninth mainline entry in the Shin Megami Tensei series.Players become the Nahobino, a fusion of human and demon awakened in the post-apocalyptic realm of Da’at - an alternate Tokyo wracked by divine conflict after the Creator’s death. The gameplay features free-roaming traversal across thematic environments, strategic turn-based battles using the series’ iconic Press Turn system, and mechanics such as demon negotiation, fusion, magic ("Magatsuhi" skills), and upgrades via Glory or Demon Essences.In June 2024, Atlus released Shin Megami Tensei V: Vengeance, an enhanced edition featuring a new storyline route, additional demons, gameplay refinements, and quality-of-life improvements across multiple platforms.

The Drifter is a 2D point-and-click adventure game set in a stylized pixel-art world with cinematic animation and a synth-driven soundtrack. It follows Mick Carter, a drifter who returns to his hometown for a funeral and quickly finds himself entangled in a violent conspiracy. After surviving a murder attempt and experiencing a moment of apparent death, Mick becomes the target of a mysterious group and begins to experience strange visions. As he searches for answers, he uncovers a larger web of corporate secrecy and supernatural phenomena. The game blends noir elements, science fiction, and pulp thriller tropes.Gameplay focuses on puzzle-solving tied closely to the narrative flow. Players navigate scenes, interact with characters, and collect and combine objects to solve puzzles. The game is described as thriller with a fast pace with few quiet moments between escalating events., so inventory is often reset between chapters to keep puzzles contained within local scenes and prevent clutter. Most tasks also offer limited item options, although there are also some multi-step and chapter-spanning puzzles. Pixel hunting is avoided through environmental cues like lighting guide exploration, and a hotspot-revealing function.The game can be played with a mouse or a twin-stick controller setup. The latter uses a radial selection wheel to highlight interactable objects. Dialogue is fully voice-acted, and much of the narrative is delivered through Mick's frequent monologues. His internal commentary is a constant presence and shifts in tone depending on the context—ranging from intense or dramatic to sardonic or humorous. Throughout the game, Mick encounters recurring characters, such as his estranged sister and ex-wife.

column1: The Hundred Line: Last Defense Academy
column3: The Hundred Line: Last Defense Academy is a hybrid visual novel and tactical role-playing game (TRPG). It blends character-driven storytelling with strategic, turn-based combat.The game follows Takumi Sakumo, a teenager living in the seemingly peaceful Tokyo Residential Complex, an artificial environment designed to shelter humanity after an unspecified global catastrophe. His routine life is disrupted when mysterious creatures known as the "Invaders" attack. In the chaos, Takumi unlocks a latent ability called Hemoanima, granting him the power to transform and fight back. Following this event, Takumi awakens at the Last Defense Academy, an isolated facility where select teenagers gifted with Hemoanima are tasked with defending humanity. The students are informed they must survive and repel the Invaders for 100 consecutive days, after which a powerful, world-saving weapon will activate.The game combines traditional visual novel elements—such as dialogue-driven storytelling and branching choices—with accessible TRPG combat mechanics. Each student possesses a unique combat role, tied to their personality and backstory, expressed through "Class Armor" and "Class Weapons." Players manage a team of these characters across grid-based battlefields, confronting various enemy types and boss encounters.Combat progression introduces new tactical layers at a steady pace, including status effects, special abilities triggered by "Voltage" (a resource generated through combat actions), and "Last Resort" moves—powerful attacks available under critical conditions, often with significant risk attached. While designed to be beginner-friendly, the system offers enough depth to engage genre veterans through party optimization and strategic planning.In addition to battles, the game incorporates social simulation mechanics reminiscent of titles like Persona.
