During "Free Time" segments, players can explore relationships with classmates, craft gifts using gathered materials, and unlock character-specific dialogue. Strengthening these bonds enhances combat performance and influences narrative outcomes, particularly during "Persuasion" events where reluctant students can be convinced to join the fight.The game's 100-day cycle provides a clear framework for its progression, with each in-game day potentially advancing the plot, character interactions, or strategic preparations. After completing an initial playthrough, the game opens into a post-game, encouraging players to explore alternate choices and outcomes. Across its branching storylines, players can uncover 100 distinct endings, reinforcing themes of hope, sacrifice, and the complexity of human relationships.

Final Fantasy VII: Remake – Intergrade is a single-player Japanese-style role-playing game. It expands upon Final Fantasy VII: Remake, continuing the reimagined events of the original Final Fantasy VII within the city of Midgar. The main story follows mercenary Cloud Strife as he joins the eco-terrorist group AVALANCHE in their struggle against the Shinra Electric Power Company, whose exploitation of the planet’s life force threatens the world’s survival. The Intergrade edition also introduces a new episode centered on Yuffie Kisaragi, a ninja operative from Wutai who infiltrates Midgar on a mission to steal a powerful Materia from Shinra and restore her homeland’s prestige.Gameplay combines real-time combat with strategic command inputs. Players directly control one character at a time while others act under AI control, switching freely among party members to coordinate attacks and abilities. The battle system balances action-oriented swordplay and ranged combat with a tactical mode that slows time for issuing spells, using items, or activating Materia-based skills. Each character specializes in distinct combat roles: Cloud excels in melee and counterattacks, Tifa in rapid strikes and juggling enemies, Barret in ranged support, and Aerith in magic. The Active Time Battle (ATB) gauge fuels all advanced actions, encouraging aggressive play to build charge while managing defense and positioning.Progression is driven by equipment and Materia customization. Weapons and armor provide attribute bonuses and skill slots, while Materia grants access to elemental magic, support effects, and summoning abilities. Experience gained from combat improves character stats and unlocks weapon upgrades through a skill tree interface. Summon Materia allows players to call powerful allies into battle, each with limited-time attacks that culminate in a cinematic finishing move. Boss encounters emphasize pattern recognition, stagger management, and use of elemental weaknesses to exploit openings.Outside combat, players explore segmented environments filled with side missions, mini-games, and optional encounters. Quest chains reward items, experience, and lore expansion, while vendors and crafting stations supply equipment upgrades. Traversal includes climbing, puzzle-solving, and environmental interactions tied to mission objectives. The Yuffie episode, Episode INTERmission, introduces a faster combat style centered on acrobatics and ranged shuriken techniques. Yuffie can combine melee strikes with ninjutsu spells that adapt elemental properties mid-combat, creating a hybrid of mobility and magic.

Ninja Gaiden: Ragebound is a 2D action platformer, blending classic Ninja Gaiden gameplay from entries in the series from the late 80's and early 90's, with modern mechanics and presentation. Players control Kenji Mozu, a young ninja from the Hayabusa clan, trained by series protagonist Ryu Hayabusa. When demons attack his village during Ryu’s absence, Kenji is forced to team up with Kumori, a skilled assassin from the rival Black Spider Clan. Their uneasy alliance becomes central to the game's narrative, as they work together to stop a demonic invasion and seal away the Demon Lord.Gameplay focuses on fast-paced, precision-based combat and platforming. Kenji uses a katana for melee attacks, while Kumori offers ranged support with kunai and special weapons. Players can switch between the two characters to combine their abilities, and unlock powerful techniques known as Ragebound Arts. Combat is further deepened by the Hypercharge system, which rewards players for defeating enemies with glowing colored auras. Each aura corresponds to a specific type of attack—such as katana strikes for blue or kunai for purple—and landing the correct hit builds a Hypercharge. This powerful charge can then be used for instant kills or to stagger bosses. There is also the Guillotine Boost, a movement mechanic that lets players bounce off enemies and projectiles for chained aerial navigation and attacks.Levels are linear with collectibles, hidden paths, optional challenges and boss fights. The game includes a scoring system that encourages speed, combo chains, and creative use of abilities. There are optional difficulty modifiers, bonus stages, and unlockable equipment.

Rogue Legacy 2 is a single-player roguelike action platformer game, and sequel to Rogue Legacy (2013). The player takes the role of a long line of heroes sent to explore and conquer a constantly shifting kingdom. Each adventurer is a descendant of the last, inheriting both the fortune and the flaws of their bloodline. When one character dies, a new heir is chosen from a pool of possible descendants, each with unique traits, abilities, and classes. The goal is to explore the ever-changing castle and surrounding biomes, defeat powerful bosses, and secure a legacy that allows future generations to delve deeper.Gameplay combines side-scrolling combat and exploration with procedurally generated levels. Players must fight enemies, navigate traps, and uncover hidden passages across themed zones, ranging from castles and forests to subterranean ruins. Combat is real-time and emphasizes class abilities, timing, and mobility, with each class wielding a distinct weapon type and set of skills. Enemies scale in complexity across biomes, requiring adaptation as the player progresses.Progression follows the roguelite structure, where gold, resources, and runes collected during a run are spent after death to upgrade the family estate. This meta-progression unlocks permanent bonuses, new character classes, expanded skill trees, and blacksmith and enchantress services that allow customization of gear and magical runes. Each heir also brings unique character traits, such as colorblindness, gigantism, or comedic quirks, which affect gameplay and encourage varied playstyles.Secondary systems include relics and blessings discovered within biomes, offering temporary powers that can dramatically alter a run. These often come with trade-offs, such as reduced health in exchange for powerful abilities. Heirlooms function as permanent unlocks earned through special trials, expanding traversal with abilities like double jumps, dashes, and grappling hooks. These not only make exploration more fluid but also open up new paths in previously visited biomes.

column1: Metal Gear Solid Δ: Snake Eater
column3: Metal Gear Solid Δ: Snake Eater is a remake of the 2004 PlayStation 2 title Metal Gear Solid 3: Snake Eater, built in a new engine for modern platforms. The remake retains the original's storyline, characters, and voice acting, while presenting the game with new visuals, updated controls, and quality-of-life improvements.The narrative is unchanged: players take on the role of Naked Snake during the Cold War as he infiltrates Soviet territory to rescue scientist Sokolov, confront Colonel Volgin, and ultimately face his mentor, The Boss. All major cut-scenes and dialogue sequences are preserved, with the original voice cast returning and some new lines added.Core gameplay remains focused on survival stealth, with camouflage, stamina management, food hunting, and real-time wound treatment intact. Boss encounters such as The End or The Sorrow preserve their original mechanics and unusual player-driven solutions, while quirks like "time paradox" game overs and the optional Snake vs. Monkey mini-game also return. For the Xbox versions it is Snake Vs Bomberman as unlike Bomberman, Ape Escape is a Sony-owned IP. The rework of the separate game that is a Zone of the Enders 3 prototype, is also remade, by a separate developer.Changes in Metal Gear Solid Δ primarily affect presentation and usability. The graphics are rebuilt with realistic jungle environments, detailed character models, and advanced animations, while audio has been remastered with enhanced spatial design. Players can choose between classic controls faithful to the original or modernized controls that allow free aiming and smoother movement. Menus for camouflage and equipment are streamlined, reducing interruptions during play, and new accessibility options include scalable text, remappable inputs, aim assists, and color filters. A new clothing damage system visually tracks Snake's injuries over time, and extra content also includes a new multiplayer mode, Fox Hunt, which was added post release.

Immortality is a single-player interactive movie and narrative investigation game. The story centers on Marissa Marcel, an actress who appeared in three films that were never released. After completing her final project, she disappeared without explanation. The player takes on the role of an investigator with access to film reels, behind-the-scenes clips, and outtakes. The objective is to examine this archive, piece together the events of Marcel’s life and career, and uncover the truth about what happened to her.Gameplay revolves around reviewing full-motion video clips and using a match-cutting mechanic to navigate between them. At any moment, the player can pause a scene and click on an object, face, or symbol of interest. Doing so will transport them to a different clip featuring the same item or theme. This process creates a branching network of footage, gradually unlocking new clips that reveal more of the mystery. The player is free to choose their path of exploration, with no set order to the discoveries.There is no combat, inventory, or traditional progression system. Instead, the challenge lies in observation and deduction. Clips range from in-character movie performances to candid moments on set, allowing players to distinguish between the fictional narratives of the films and the real-life drama surrounding their production. The game automatically catalogs clips once viewed, enabling players to revisit them at any time.

The Alters is a survival game set on a hostile alien planet. It focuses on the struggles of Jan Dolski, a space miner stranded there after a mining mission gone awry. The main premise revolves around Jan’s ability to create “Alters”—alternate versions of himself who diverge from him at key points in his life. Each Alter has a unique set of skills, knowledge, and traits, reflecting choices and paths that the original Jan might have taken. Players use these Alters to perform specialized tasks, solve problems, and keep their base functional under increasingly dire conditions.Gameplay combines exploration, base-building, and resource management inspired by Satisfactory. Players control Jan and his growing team of Alters to mine resources, construct facilities, and navigate hazardous areas of the alien world. The base itself is a large, wheel-shaped structure designed to stay just ahead of the lethal rays of the nearby sun. Players must power and expand their base by attaching modules and infrastructure, much in the style of games like Fallout Shelter or X-COM.The game introduces a “Tree of Life” system that lets players view the different paths their character's life might have taken and create Alters from those timelines. Each Alter brings their own expertise and perspectives to the base’s operations, adding depth to problem-solving and interpersonal relationships. Players must manage the physical and psychological well-being of their crew, addressing their needs and disputes to avoid rebellion and conflict.Exploration plays a key role in the gameplay, with players needing to venture outside their base to gather resources, discover points of interest, and respond to environmental hazards. Anomalous creatures and radiation-rich areas pose additional risks to their missions. The game's day-and-night cycle adds urgency to these tasks, reflecting the slow advance of the sun and the danger it brings.The narrative explores themes of survival, regret, regret of choices, and the human will to persevere under extraordinary conditions. Players face moral and strategic decisions that affect both their ability to stay alive and the relationships between their various Alters.

Return to Monkey Island is a point-and-click adventure and a direct sequel to Monkey Island 2: LeChuck's Revenge (1991). It has the original creator Ron Gilbert back at the helm and picks up directly after the events of that game. However, it also incorporates and acknowledges the characters and events from later titles such as The Curse of Monkey Island (1997), Escape from Monkey Island (2000) and Tales of Monkey Island (2009).This game focuses on the series' protagonist Guybrush Threepwood as he sets out to finally reveal the secret of the Monkey Island. A short prelude explains the ending of the previous game, why this title is told as a flashback and an optional scrapbook available in the main menu is provided with a brief history of the events of all games. The adventure is divided in several parts and starts on Mêlée Island where Guybrush, reprised by Dominic Amato, once again finds himself without a ship and crew to travel to Monkey Island. Mêlée island has also changed, with Carla the swordmaster as the new governor, Elaine advocating social and health issues, and a new pirate leadership refusing to fund Guybrush's venture. Many characters from all titles return in this game, such as Stan the salesman, Otis, Wally the map maker, the Voodoo Lady and Murray the talking skull, but also many new characters. Next to the familiar Monkey Island and Mêlée Island there are entirely new locations such as Brr Muda and Terror Island.A classic point-and-click interface is used to experience the story, talk to characters and solve puzzles. When hovering over a character or object, usually one or two options are provided: to examine and to interact. Items can be picked up and are stored in an inventory where they can be combined or used in the environment. There is also a todo list as an inventory item where quests are tracked. A separate action is available to highlight all hotspots in the environment. The game can be played in an easy Casual mode or the Hard more with more puzzles. There is also a separate Writer's Cut option with more text and dialogue, available for both modes. Hints are provided through another in-game item, a hint book provided by the Voodoo Lady. The environment is also littered with optional trivia cards stored in a trivia book. Players need to answer a question about the series. If it is answered incorrectly the card disappears.The game retains its humorous approach, often breaking the fourth wall. The game uses an entirely new visual style headed by Rex Crowle and similar to the one used in his game Knights and Bikes (2019). It aims to resemble a picture book or a pop-up book with exaggerated character features, using 2D and no longer the pixel art of the original two games or the sharp cartoon or 3D look from later titles. The original composers also return with new music.

Diablo IV is a single-player and multiplayer action role-playing game.The story takes place in Sanctuary, a world plagued by demons, cultists, and corrupted humans. After centuries of fragile peace, the return of Lilith, daughter of Mephisto, threatens to plunge the world into chaos once again. The player takes the role of a wandering adventurer who becomes entangled in the struggle between the forces of Heaven and Hell, traveling across the regions of Sanctuary while pursuing Lilith’s followers and uncovering dark secrets. The overarching goal is to combat demonic corruption while seeking to restore a measure of stability to the land.The narrative unfolds through cinematic cutscenes and dialogue with key characters, revealing the consequences of ancient conflicts and the manipulation of mortals by higher powers. Along the way, the player can choose different approaches in conversations and decide which quests to pursue, but the central focus remains on confronting Lilith and her growing influence.Gameplay centers on real-time combat viewed from an isometric perspective. Players select one of several character classes such as Barbarian, Sorcerer, Rogue, Druid, or Necromancer, each offering distinct abilities, weapons, and playstyles. Combat involves chaining attacks, using cooldown-based skills, and combining class-specific mechanics such as elemental magic or shapeshifting. Enemies appear in large groups, including elite and boss-level foes that require positioning, resource management, and timely use of abilities.Progression is tied to experience points earned from defeating enemies and completing quests. Leveling up grants points that can be assigned to an expansive skill tree, allowing specialization in offensive or defensive powers. Equipment such as weapons, armor, and magical items can be looted, crafted, or traded, with rarity tiers that influence power and special attributes. The inventory system allows players to manage limited space while prioritizing gear improvements, socketing gems, and using consumables like healing potions.The world of Sanctuary is presented as an interconnected open map with multiple regions that can be explored seamlessly. Dungeons are randomly generated in layout and enemy placement, offering replayability. Mounts provide faster travel across large areas, while waypoints allow quick navigation between key locations. Events such as world bosses, strongholds, and random encounters provide optional challenges that reward valuable items and resources.Multiplayer integration enables cooperative play, trading, and participation in large-scale world events. Player versus player zones are designated areas where combat against other adventurers is possible, with rewards tied to risk. Seasonal events introduce new mechanics, quests, and cosmetic rewards for limited durations, encouraging repeated playthroughs. While the main storyline is designed for solo play, the game requires an online connection and supports shared world features. This structure means that dungeons can be tackled alone or with others, and large world events often require multiple players to succeed. Seasonal characters, once created, exist only for that season’s duration before transferring to the main roster, maintaining a cycle of new challenges and progression systems.

column3: Suikoden I&II HD Remaster: Gate Rune & Dunan Unification Wars is a compilation that contains remastered releases of the first two titles in the Suikoden series, both originally released for the PlayStation:The remastered releases have HD backgrounds, new effects for the pixel art animations, new ambient backgrounds sounds as well new sound effects for the battles, auto saving, faster battles and a logbook for conversations.

NORCO is a single-player point-and-click adventure game. The story is set in a near-future version of Louisiana where decaying industry, corporate expansion, and environmental collapse have reshaped the region. The player takes the role of Kay, a young woman returning to her hometown of Norco after her mother’s death. Her brother Blake has disappeared, and as Kay investigates his absence, she becomes entangled in a conspiracy involving oil refineries, private security forces, and religious sects. The narrative blends Southern Gothic atmosphere with dystopian science fiction, framing the journey as both a family drama and an exploration of a changing landscape.Gameplay follows the traditions of classic point-and-click adventures. Players explore hand-painted environments, clicking to move between screens and interact with objects or characters. Conversations advance the story and often present choices that reveal background details or influence character relationships. The interface includes an inventory system where collected items are examined, combined, or used to solve puzzles that block progression.Progression is largely narrative-driven. Instead of complex inventory chains, puzzles often involve logic or dialogue-based challenges, requiring the player to pay attention to details revealed in the environment and text. Some sequences include light mini-game mechanics, such as combat presented through quick input challenges or memory-based interactions, but the focus remains on storytelling rather than mechanical difficulty.A unique feature is the “Mindmap” system, which serves as a visual notebook of characters, events, and key concepts. As the player advances, Kay’s thoughts and memories appear here, letting the player review important information or examine new connections. This system supplements the narrative by clarifying relationships and motivations, helping the player track the game’s layered plot.Branching dialogue choices allow for subtle variations in how events unfold. While the overall story has a fixed structure, individual conversations may change how characters respond or what information is revealed. Exploration is rewarded with optional interactions that expand the world’s lore, from overheard conversations to hidden environmental details.

Silent Hill f is a survival horror game released as a mainline entry in the long-running Silent Hill series. It departs from the franchise's traditional American setting and relocates its narrative to 1960s Japan. The game presents an entirely self-contained story centered on a new protagonist and original location, while retaining the series' focus on psychological horror, oppressive atmosphere, and disturbing creature design.Set in the rural village of Ebisugaoka, the story follows Hinako Shimizu, a high school student whose troubled family life and personal traumas manifest in terrifying ways as her home town becomes engulfed in fog and overrun with grotesque monstrosities. The narrative blends folklore, psychological distress, and themes of social repression, child abuse, and alienation. As in prior entries, reality frequently fractures into nightmarish "otherworlds", where environments and encounters serve as metaphors for the protagonist’s inner turmoil. Players uncover Hinako's past and motivations through exploration, puzzles, and journal entries, with the story offering five endings that gradually expand on the truth behind the events in Ebisugaoka.Gameplay follows the survival horror tradition of limited resources and puzzle-solving but introduces several departures from earlier Silent Hill titles. Combat is strictly melee-based, with Hinako wielding improvised and breakable weapons such as pipes and bats, as firearms are absent. A stamina system governs attacks and dodges, while a sanity meter adds an additional layer of vulnerability. Exploration alternates between the decaying streets of Ebisugaoka and a surreal shrine-like otherworld overseen by a fox-masked figure, where Hinako temporarily gains supernatural powers and indestructible weapons. Puzzles draw heavily on Japanese cultural motifs and folklore.

Sword of the Sea is an atmospheric surfing exploration game. You play as the Wraith, reborn in a desolate world of endless dunes, gliding across waves of sand on the ancient Hoversword. Part surfboard, part skateboard, part snowboard, the Hoversword lets you carve, soar, and trick your way through vast landscapes while restoring life to a long-buried ocean.The game blends fluid movement with gentle exploration and environmental puzzles. The game emphasizes flow—missed jumps or sloppy tricks rarely break momentum, keeping the ride meditative. While there is a main path to follow, there are many optional challenges with hidden treasure chests, a tetra currency to collect, hidden shells and tiles, trick high score attack challenges and other secrets. Optional shrines can be visit to learn more about the game's world and history.Often, when restoring water to the world, new means of exploration become available. The game is entirely HUDless and when dying the main character immediately respawns. The tetra currency can be exchanged at some locations for additional abilities. Other abilities become available by progressing through the game. Environments range from glittering deserts and icy peaks to drowned ruins filled with marine life.

column3: Command & Conquer: Remastered Collection is an updated release of the following content:Aside from new graphics that can be toggled on and off in singleplayer, both games come with a new multiplayer system, fixes for old bugs, new audio system containing various music variants (original, OST disc, remastered, bonus tracks by Frank Klepacki and The Tiberian Sons, unreleased tracks), quality-of-life improvements (unit type select, skirmish AI in the original Command & Conquer, multi-queues in the sidebar, replay system, etc.), and a map editor. column3: OlliOlli World is a single-player skateboarding platform game. The story is set in Radlandia, a colorful world where skateboarding is not only a pastime but a spiritual path. The protagonist is a customizable skater who embarks on a journey to discover the mystical Skate Gods and achieve Gnarvana, a higher state of skateboarding enlightenment. Guided by a cast of eccentric companions, the player travels through themed regions, meeting challenges set by the gods while uncovering the culture and legends of Radlandia.Gameplay is presented as a side-scrolling platformer with trick-based skating. Levels are built with multiple routes, rails, and obstacles, encouraging both speed and creativity. Players chain tricks together by flicking the analog stick to perform flips, grabs, and grinds, then land precisely to maintain momentum. Flow and rhythm are central: successful sequences keep the skater moving smoothly while poorly timed inputs can break combos or result in a fall.Progression through the campaign requires completing stages in sequence, but levels often include secondary objectives and optional paths that reward skillful play. Scoring is based on trick variety, combo length, and timing, with leaderboards encouraging replayability. Certain challenges unlock cosmetic rewards, new routes, or access to more difficult stages. Levels escalate in complexity, gradually introducing hazards such as moving platforms and environmental changes that test reaction speed and mastery of controls.The game includes an extensive customization system. Players design their skater’s appearance with unlockable outfits, boards, and cosmetic items, reflecting both personal style and progress. While customization does not alter gameplay, it provides a sense of individuality in both solo play and online score comparisons.Daily challenges and asynchronous multiplayer leaderboards allow players to compete for high scores globally. A level generator called the Gnarvana Portal creates random skate runs based on selected preferences.

A Plague Tale: Requiem is a single-player stealth-based action game. The story follows Amicia de Rune and her younger brother Hugo as they struggle to survive in southern France after the events of A Plague Tale: Innocence. Hugo’s mysterious illness, connected to the plague of rats spreading across the countryside, grows increasingly unstable, driving the siblings to search for a cure while pursued by mercenaries, soldiers, and the Inquisition. The narrative emphasizes their bond, with Amicia bearing the responsibility of protecting Hugo while adapting to a world that forces her into more violent choices.The gameplay combines stealth, environmental puzzles, and resource management. Amicia retains her sling as her primary tool, useful for striking targets, distracting enemies, or breaking objects. As the game progresses, she gains access to a crossbow that provides more direct ways of dealing with armored opponents. She can also craft alchemical ammunition that can ignite fires, extinguish light sources, or manipulate rat swarms. Stealth remains the preferred approach, encouraging players to use cover, control patrol patterns, and create diversions to avoid open confrontation.The rat swarms are central to the gameplay and serve as both a danger and a weapon. They move dynamically across the environment and respond to light and sound, requiring players to manipulate torches, braziers, and alchemical tools to carve safe paths. Swarms can also be turned against enemies by removing their light sources or breaking their defenses. Hugo develops abilities that allow him to sense and influence the rats, giving players temporary control of swarms or heightened perception of threats.Progression unfolds across linear chapters that introduce new challenges and mechanics. Resources are scarce, forcing players to gather materials for crafting ammunition, tools, and upgrades. Workbenches allow improvements to Amicia’s equipment, enhancing accuracy, efficiency, or carrying capacity. A skill system evolves according to the player’s actions, with frequent use of stealth, aggression, or alchemy leading to gradual growth in those styles. This approach shapes Amicia’s abilities without relying on traditional experience points.

Stray is an action game with puzzle elements following a cat surviving in a neon-lit, decaying cybercity inspired by Kowloon Walled City. One day, the cat is separated from his family and tumbles down deep inside the underbelly of the city. Looking for a way back, it roams the environments and meets the droids left behind, inhabiting the world devoid of the humans who designed them. The game mixes different types of gameplay in a largely linear experience. The cat navigates the environment by jumping on objects to find a way up or through sections. (Optional) prompts appear where it is possible to navigate and these can be strung together in a fluid, parkour-like chain.One type of gameplay is through linear corridors, slowly exploring and finding a route. Other sections are fast-paced, involving Zurks, creatures that form groups and try to jump the cat. They attach themselves to the protagonist and can be shaken loose, but only for a while when their number is low. It is possible to die in these sections, so quick navigation is required combined with puzzle-solving. Later on a Defluxor device becomes available with brief use to destroy them using UV light. A third type of section is more of a hub environment with a large amount of freedom. Locations can be explored in any direction, getting on rooftops, sneaking inside buildings through windows and solving puzzles along the way. These sections often have goals locating specific items or droids, but also a lot of optional quests through collectibles and locating memories that provide more information about what happened to the city. It is possible to talk to characters through the B-12 flying drone, which the cat meets early on and is carried on his back. The droid is able to offer hints, light up the surroundings with a torch, translate the environment and can communicate with other characters. There are also items that can be picked up and are stored in an inventory. Some sections incorporate stealth, sneaking past characters or quickly avoiding security droids.A lot of the gameplay revolves around typical cat behaviour interwoven with the game mechanics. It is possible to meow to attract the attention of enemies, push down items off objects, hide in cardboard boxes and jump on levers to activate them. The cat can also scratch doors to get the attention of those inside. Many of these interactions are also optional, such as lying down to sleep or nuzzling up legs.

Minishoot' Adventures is a 2D top-down action game that blends elements of the bullet hell shooter and Metroidvania genres. Players control a small hovercraft navigating a handcrafted world filled with dungeons, enemies, and exploration. The main objective is to reclaim stolen powers, upgrade the player's ship, and defeat bosses in challenging combat encounters.Players shoot their way through enemies using a variety of weapons, which can be upgraded as the player progresses. Combat is combined with exploration, with the world map initially incomplete. New areas are unlocked by gaining abilities that improve combat and exploration capabilities. Friendly craft can also be rescued and they offer various forms of assistance.The game incorporates a non-linear structure, where players can explore various interconnected zones, each with challenges, secrets, and treasures. The game has an emphasis on customization, allowing players to upgrade their ship and abilities. Players encounter both challenging Bullet Hell boss fights and simpler Zelda-style dungeons, each with its own puzzles and combat sequences.The game features adjustable difficulty options to accommodate both casual players and veterans of the genre with three difficulty modes, aiming assistance, and auto-fire options.

column3: Ninja Gaiden 4 is a 3D hack-and-slash action game, serving as a modern revival of the long-running Ninja Gaiden series. The game introduces a new protagonist, Yakumo of the Raven Clan, while also featuring playable chapters with returning hero Ryu Hayabusa.Gameplay retains the series’ signature high-speed melee combat, emphasizing precision, counterattacks, and resource management. Players can wield multiple weapons, perform classic moves such as the Flying Swallow and Izuna Drop, and execute powerful Ultimate Techniques by absorbing essence from defeated foes. A new system, the Bloodraven Form, allows Yakumo to transform his weapon into alternate forms that can break guards, interrupt attacks, or unleash devastating combo. Combat depth is expanded through upgrade systems tied to Ninja Coins and Weapon EXP, along with optional side missions and high-difficulty Purgatory Gate challenges.The game features a 10-hour campaign set in a near-future Tokyo consumed by the miasma of an ancient dragon. Levels include linear missions with occasional traversal sequences, optional boss fights, and secret collectibles. Post-game content includes Master Ninja difficulty, Combat Trials, and replayable stages.

Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor is a single-player roguelike horde survival game. The game takes place in the hostile caverns of Hoxxes IV, a planet rich in minerals but infested with deadly creatures. Players take the role of one of the dwarves from the Deep Rock Galactic mining company, sent into procedurally generated caves to gather resources, survive endless swarms, and escape with their lives. Unlike its cooperative predecessor, Deep Rock Galactic, this installment is a solitary mission, with survival depending solely on the player’s ability to endure and adapt in the depths.Each expedition begins with a chosen class of dwarf, equipped with distinct starting weapons and abilities. The player’s goal is to mine, shoot, and progress through waves of insectoid enemies while collecting minerals that fuel upgrades. Runs continue until the dwarf is overwhelmed or successfully completes the objectives for that dive. The structure blends mining with survival, making every descent a balance between risk and reward.Gameplay revolves around auto-firing combat combined with directional movement and positioning. Weapons automatically discharge at nearby enemies, but the player must manage dodging, spacing, and navigation to survive increasingly dense swarms. Each class features its own arsenal, such as shotguns, flamethrowers, or rifles, and these can be enhanced with modifiers collected during runs. Progress through the caves introduces tougher foes, environmental hazards, and a need for constant resource gathering.Progression takes the form of roguelike loops. Minerals gathered during missions are used to unlock permanent upgrades, new weapons, and additional character classes between runs. Within a single dive, temporary upgrades can be selected as the dwarf levels up, granting improvements such as faster firing rates, greater area-of-effect attacks, or defensive buffs. Inventory management is streamlined, focusing on weapon upgrades, perks, and resource accumulation rather than traditional equipment slots.The caves themselves are destructible and dynamic. Mining for minerals is a core mechanic, allowing the player to carve paths through rock while fighting off waves of glyphids and other creatures. Terrain destruction can provide temporary safe spaces or open routes to escape danger. Enemies spawn in escalating waves, often overwhelming the player with sheer numbers.

Batman: Arkham Shadow is a VR game set in the Arkhamverse. It takes place between Arkham Origins and Arkham Asylum and follows Batman as he tries to stop the villain Rat King and his gang from destroying Gotham on the Fourth of July. It was a pack-in title for the Meta Quest 3 and 3S models from the 3S's launch, until April 30, 2025.

Vampire Survivors is a single-player roguelike horde survival game. The setting places the player in rural landscapes plagued by monsters, where they control a chosen character who must withstand continuous waves of supernatural enemies. Each run begins with only a simple weapon and limited mobility, but survival requires gathering resources, destroying countless foes, and holding out for as long as possible against an ever-growing horde.Gameplay centers on automatic attacks and constant movement. Weapons fire on their own once obtained, leaving the player to focus entirely on positioning, dodging, and navigating dense swarms of enemies. Surviving longer rewards experience gems dropped by defeated creatures, which grant level-ups. Each level-up presents randomized weapon or passive upgrades, encouraging adaptation to the run’s circumstances and offering the possibility to combine items into stronger evolved forms.Combat escalates with waves of bats, skeletons, werewolves, and other monsters filling the screen in increasing numbers. The objective is not to defeat all foes but to endure until the survival timer reaches its limit, typically thirty minutes, after which an unavoidable final enemy appears to end the run. Because of this design, progress comes not from winning battles but from outlasting the relentless enemy density.Progression carries across runs through a meta-upgrade system. Players earn gold to purchase permanent enhancements such as improved health, faster movement, or additional projectiles, which apply to all future characters. Numerous characters can be unlocked, each with unique starting weapons and traits. Stages also expand over time, with new maps, enemies, and environmental hazards being revealed. Collectibles known as relics introduce new mechanics like permanent arcana cards, which alter weapon behaviors or unlock special synergies. Hidden secrets and conditions open access to additional characters, stages, and powerful items.

Unpacking is a game about unpacking items and fitting them in a new location after moving. Starting in 1997, each level offers a new location and a new period in the protagonist's life as they move to a new environment with eight periods in total. It always starts with one or multiple empty rooms filled with cardboard boxes. A single bedroom at first, players eventually need to unpack for an entire house with many rooms. Selecting the cardboard box changes the cursor into an object lifted from inside. It can then be placed in the room, such as inside cabinets, on top of a shelf on a desk etc. The box disappears automatically when there are no more items inside. Most items can be put anywhere, but after everything is unpacked incorrect placements are highlighted in red. For instance: a toothbrush cannot be stored on a desk, but needs to be placed in the bathroom. There is some freedom and there is no time pressure, but only when all items are in a correct location is the environment completed. Because there are many objects that need a location, there is some puzzling involved to make everything fit.Items from boxes are not always in the correct environment, so the player needs to move them between rooms. It is possible to move between rooms at any time, as well as zooming and scrolling, for instance to get a good look at a specific object. Some items can be stacked. It is also possible to rotate objects and sometimes this is done automatically, for instance when moving a rolled up poster towards a wall so it can be hung. After a level is completed pictures (screenshots) can be taken and it is possible to decorate them as well as apply filters. The sped up version of the unpacking process can be viewed again through an animation or a GIF.

Marvel's Spider-Man: Miles Morales is the second game in the PlayStation exclusive Marvel's Spider-Man series, following Marvel's Spider-Man (2018). It is centered around Miles Morales, a fictional comic book superhero who becomes Spider-Man as a Black teenager of Puerto Rican ancestry on his mother's side, following the death of Peter Parker. The game handles it differently compared to the original storyline in the comic books, continuing the narrative of the first game (and especially the DLC The City That Never Sleeps) where Miles Morales is bitten by a genetically-enhanced spider and gained powers similar to Peter Parker's. Miles trains under Parker and is still integrating in the role of a Spider-Man. In the game Parker does not die, but leaves to join his girlfriend Mary Jane Watson to cover a civil war, leaving Miles as the only webslinger in New York. The story focuses on the campaign of his mother Rio Morales, and the defense of his home neighborhood in Harlem and New York City against a high-tech criminal army called the Underground and Roxxon Energy Corporation who are in a gang war.The game builds on the same type of gameplay as the original game, offering a large open world that can be explored at a fast pace by running on buildings and swinging with web shots. Most of the Manhatten map is still identical to the one of the original game, as the game is more of a smaller contained follow-up than a full-blown sequel. It now has a different theme however as it is set around Christmas time. Various types of quests and missions are offered with a mix of fights against groups of characters or relying on a more stealth based approach. Many are provided through an app citizen use to contact him. Stealth receives more attention in this title as Miles has the ability to become invisible for a short time. Other new abilities include bioelectricity where electricity is absorbed to use it as a weapon, for instance launching a Venom Punch, but also as a means to solve environment based puzzles.As in the first game there are many collectibles (often providing bonuses and gadget upgrades) and side missions to earn activity tokens and experience points. Gradually more power are unlocked for Miles' new suits or for his visor. Some items also add to the story, for instance through time capsules that show portions of Miles early life and audio-focused collectibles that provide information about his family.

Battlefield 6 is a first-person shooter that continues the long-running Battlefield franchise with a return to large-scale, class-based multiplayer combat following the more experimental Battlefield 2042 (2021).The game reintroduces traditional Battlefield mechanics such as the four-class system, large destructible environments, and vehicle-based warfare across expansive maps supporting up to 64 players. The focus is on territory control through returning modes including Conquest, Rush, and Breakthrough, alongside smaller-scale variants such as Team Deathmatch and Domination. These are joined by Portal, a map and mode editor enabling user-generated content drawn from past Battlefield titles.Gameplay emphasizes combined-arms combat across both infantry and vehicle roles. Battles unfold dynamically, with players free to specialize as engineers, medics, assault troops, or support roles. The series' hallmark of emergent, player-driven scenarios remains central, allowing for varied tactics ranging from aerial dogfights to ground-level infantry skirmishes. Weapon handling and ballistics have been redesigned for faster, more responsive gunplay, moving closer to contemporary military shooters with refined recoil patterns, faster projectile speeds, and a Gunsmith-style weapon customization system.The launch version features nine maps, including Mirak Valley, New Sobek City, Operation Firestorm, and Iberian Offensive. Larger maps prioritize vehicle combat and open engagements, while smaller arenas focus on close-quarters firefights. Environmental destruction and real-time weather effects return, enhancing both strategy and spectacle.Progression and customization follow a familiar structure of unlockable weapons, attachments, and character cosmetics earned through play. Equipment and vehicle loadouts can be adjusted mid-match, and players earn experience for teamwork-oriented actions such as reviving allies, repairing vehicles, and capturing objectives.A single-player campaign is included, following the operations of the spec-ops unit Dagger 13 in missions set across urban and desert environments. The campaign uses scripted objectives and linear progression, focusing on squad-based infiltration and sabotage missions. Despite featuring traditional Battlefield themes of large-scale warfare, the campaign limits direct vehicle control and destructibility compared to the multiplayer component.

Gradius: Origins is a collection that celebrates 40 years of the Gradius series of side-scrolling space based shooters. This release contains six arcade titles from the series with seventeen variations / versions in total, including the AM Show Version of Gradius III made available on home consoles and PC for the first time. It also includes a seventh game, created specifically for this collection: Salamander III. All games have quality of life improvements and extras such as historical artwork, sound galleries, guides, original promotional material, the options to rewind, multiple game modes and more.The included games are:Salamander III is unique to this collection. It is the first original Gradius-related game to be released in 17 years (the last being Gradius: ReBirth released in 2008, or 14 years if counting Otomedius Excellent from 2011). It continues the Salamander spin-off series with six stages and a mixture of classic and new gameplay elements. Players control either the Vic Viper Type L or the Lord British MK III, navigating stages filled with enemies, environmental hazards, and boss encounters. The game supports solo play or local two-player co-op.Combat focuses on familiar power-ups such as Speed Up, Missiles, Lasers, and Ripple Lasers, which can now be upgraded by collecting duplicates. A new "Burst Mode" temporarily powers up weapons into more destructive forms, like Hyper Ray and Buster Ripple, before cooling down. Another addition is the "Multiple Change" system, allowing players to customize the formation of their "Multiples"—satellite units that mirror the player's firepower—up to a maximum of eight. It provides a mix of the classic power-up system from the Salamander series, as well as new power-ups shared from Gradius: Neo.The story follows the princess of Latis piloting her brother's restored fighter craft against a renewed threat from the Salamander Force. She is joined by the Gradius Army as they confront returning bosses and new enemies across a range of biomes, including asteroid fields, volcanic deserts, and magnetic planetoids. While narrative elements remain minimal, the game builds on the visual and mechanical legacy of the series, offering updated sprite work, modernized sound design, and remixed music tracks that reference previous entries.

Nioh 2: Complete Edition is a compilation release. It includes:For PC and PS5, this is the first release of the game for the platforms. If, for the PC version, the game was purchased through Steam in the first three weeks between 5th and 26th February, two additional skins are provided: Ornate Gold Armor and Sohaya Deserter Garb. That version also includes a Valve helmet exclusive to the Steam release.For the PlayStation versions the content is identical, but it is referred to as a Remastered version of the game. Purchasing the game digitally provides a copy for both PS4 and PS5. Next to the bundled DLC content the PS5 Remastered version targets 120 FPS and has cross-generation multiplayer. Data from the original PS4 version of the game can be imported. Owners of the original PS4 version on disc can receive the PS5 digital version for free.

Travellers Rest is a single-player simulation game. The player takes the role of an innkeeper in a medieval fantasy setting, inheriting a small tavern with the goal of turning it into a thriving establishment. Guests of all sorts pass through the inn’s doors, from weary travelers to merchants and adventurers, and it is the player’s responsibility to keep them fed, rested, and satisfied. There is no overarching narrative beyond the management and growth of the tavern, with progress determined by how well the player maintains and expands their business.From the start, the tavern is bare and modest. The player must furnish it, brew drinks, cook meals, and serve patrons while keeping the atmosphere welcoming. Cleaning, stocking supplies, and ensuring smooth service are part of daily operations. As the inn becomes more successful, profits can be reinvested into renovations and expansions, adding more seating, decorative flair, and new brewing or cooking equipment.Gameplay revolves around crafting and management systems. Players gather ingredients such as grains, hops, fruit, and herbs to produce beer, wine, spirits, and meals. Recipes can be customized by adjusting proportions and ingredients, leading to variations in quality and patron preference. Brewing and cooking are time-based processes, requiring careful planning so that food and drink are ready when needed. Serving customers involves quickly providing their orders while keeping tables clean and tavern morale high.Progression is tied to experience points earned in various activities like brewing, farming, cooking, and socializing. As skills increase, new recipes, crafting stations, and farming techniques become available. Farming outside the tavern is an important element, allowing the player to cultivate crops, raise animals, and secure a steady supply of raw materials. Balancing farming tasks with tavern service creates a cycle of preparation and execution that drives the game forward.The economic system plays a central role. Profits from running the inn can be used to buy seeds, ingredients, and furniture. Customers pay based on the quality of food, drinks, and overall atmosphere. Prices can be adjusted, but overcharging may discourage guests. Inventory management is key, as running out of supplies during service reduces customer satisfaction and income. Strategic investments in brewing casks, ovens, or decorative items gradually elevate the inn’s reputation.

Hrot is a single-player first-person retro shooter that borrows heavily from the original Quake, using a visual style that resembles 1990s software-style rendering with unfiltered textures and polygon jitter, combined with a color palette that consists mainly of grey and brown. Optionally the game can be played in a GL mode with hardware acceleration. It is set in Czechoslovakia after an unspecified disaster in 1986. It consists of three episodes with about eight levels each, along with a secret level. Episodes were made available over time as the game was launched in Early Access on 29th January 2021 and it was then in development for about two and half years until the full release on 16th May 2023. The first episode was available right away, the second one was added on 22nd June 2022 and the third one with the full release.The player's character emerges from a civil defense shelter deep under a Prague Metro station, having survived the disaster. Wearing a gas mask, all intruders in the country now need to be eliminated. Locations have a dark and grim setting, but there are also many quirky and humorous elements often based on soviet culture. Many of them have real, historical details and inspirations. Humans have been affected by the disaster. They wear gas masks and can often be spotted throwing up. There are also mutated creatures. The weapon arsenal consists of pistols with dual-wielding, two types of shotguns, grenades, a machine gun, a rocket launcher-like Hussite hand cannon, a crossbow, a sickle for melee combat, but also experimental weapons such as a lightning gun. A bottle of alcohol is used as a medkit and distorts the character's vision. Along the way small health pick-ups can be found as well, along with power-ups such as additional damage and a Koruna currency. The character has access to a flashlight at any moment. Enemies are heavily inspired by those in Quake, but with a soviet twist. Bosses often take on unexpected forms and there are mechanical opponents such as sentry guns, loaders and helicopters.Levels have a linear design using typical progress based on keys that need to be located to unlock doors, switches and valves. The environments are filled with socialist paraphernalia and a lot of interaction is encouraged. Most items are destructible and next to the sickle a kick is available as a melee attack. That is often required to find the secrets hidden in the levels. Many interactions are optional such as flushing toilets, destroying light bulbs, answering a phone, playing a game of football, playing a synthesizer, riding a motorcycle, playing games on a handheld or standing on a billiards table to move the balls.Encountered enemies are stored in a bestiary that can be consulted from the main menu, along with recipes that are unlocked after completing an episode. After completing a first episode an Endless mode is unlocked with wave-based arena combat based on four environments. Completed levels can be selected from a level select screen. There are five difficulty levels. When playing the campaign mode, a blank slate mode can be enabled where health and weapons are not carried over between levels.

Death's Door is an action RPG about the character Crow, a bird and also a reaper of souls. It is an employee at the Reaping Commission Headquarters, a bureaucratic institution that tasks people like Crow with soul reaping while providing commissions on successful retrievals. At the start of the game it has to bring back a giant soul, but after defeating that demonic forest spirit it is attacked from behind and the soul is stolen. Crow cannot move on until the soul is secured, so there is no choice but to help the old reaper that tricked him and collect several other giant souls that may open the titular Death's Door where the soul is now held.From a central location called the Lost Cemetery, Crow can access different areas leading to the three giant souls it needs to defeat and bring back to Death's Door. The character can be moved around freely and has two melee attacks along with a ranged attack with limited ammo. Eventually five different weapons can be unlocked and they can be changed on the fly. They vary in style, appearance and statistics such as damage, swings, range and swing time. The regular melee attack is for quick hits, while the second one can be charged or a strong attack or is executed following a dodge roll. Ammo for the ranged attack can be found through items or by hitting enemies. Melee, but especially ranged attacks are often used to solve puzzles such as hitting items or setting them on fire from a distance. Many areas require environment based puzzle-solving to collect items and progress. There are many enemies to defeat along with several larger boss fights that require figuring our patterns, dodging and sometimes puzzle-solving to discover weaknesses.There is a checkpoint and fast travel system through doors. At certain locations a door can be unlocked that leads back to the central Hall of Doors at the Reaping Commission Headquarters. From there Crow can quickly return to any area at any time or choose another door. When Crow dies he returns to the last unlocked door. At the HQ there are characters to talk to, puzzles to solve and the Soul Vault where four characteristics can be upgraded several times: strength, dexterity, haste and magic. Each upgrade requires soul energy collected by defeating enemies. Health can be replenished by picking up seeds and planting them in specific pots. Upon consumption all health is restored, but this can done only once at that pot until Crow dies or leaves the area to return.The game also contains many secrets and optional collectibles. Over time three additional magic items are unlocked as additional ranged weapons that can be switched on the fly similar to melee weapons. The new magic types often open up additional paths or secrets in previously explored areas metroidvania-style, or allow Crow to pursue a new path or open a new gate that was previously locked or out of reach. There are several characters to talk to and the game contains many humorous elements.

Age of Wonders 4 is a 4X turn-based strategy which returns the franchise to its original fantasy setting. Despite this, it combines gameplay elements from both Age of Wonders III and Age of Wonders: Planetfall with numerous changes and additions.The most obvious change is the absence of conventional races. When starting a new game, players have to choose a template for the race (humans, elves, orcs, goblins, animalkin, etc.) and then select various faction focus types, followed by customizing the traits and visuals of the ruler unit. Upon a match's end, rulers can ascend to a pantheon, from which they can be reused with their acquired skills in future matches. This will also unlock points and new cosmetic customization options. For the first time in the series, units can also be visually customized, albeit to a lesser degree than rulers. Randomly generated worlds now have 8 slots for custom options, which handle basic features like map layout and neutral army strength to modifiers for the gameplay itself.Each player now has a limit on the number of cities they can claim, but each city can annex a considerably larger amount of regions (which are also smaller in size than in Planetfall). These regions are automatically claimed with a specialization building from the assigned city's screen. A major change is seen in the city production aspect, as unit recruitment is handled by the new auto-generated resource called Draft instead of sharing Production with city buildings. This also means that cities now have two production queues, one for buildings and the other for units. Settler units have been scrapped in standard gameplay, as cities can only be claimed from others or evolved from outposts built by hero/ruler units. Heroes no longer join the player randomly, but only when their hero limit is raised, most commonly by building/claiming a new city. Finally, city sieges have been introduced as a gameplay mechanic.Diplomacy has seen a slight improvement as well, with different and more meaningful proclamations added, some options even being brought from Planetfall covert operations. This allows for more varied communications between players. Free cities also make a return, with diplomatic options vastly expanded. Full vassalage takes more time to build up relations towards, as there are multiple relation stages, but phases in between bring their overlord economic benefits.The techtree is represented by a literal tree graphic split to several different branches, and its elements require the Imperium resource to purchase. Tomes are a more combat-oriented military research option, with each one bringing a new level of spells, upgrades and units which can be mixed to the player's liking.Side quests no longer require visiting specific sites, and can occur seemingly at random, with several options given to the player, each bringing different bonuses and/or penalties. Hostile NPC army spawners have also seen an upgrade - they take up an entire region instead of a single tile, and are initially dormant until their territory is trespassed upon. They vary in size, with larger ones being better-defended.The game is playable in single- and multiplayer (online and hot seat), with a map editor and several other tools bundled in. Cross-play multiplayer capabilities between platforms were implemented in the Watcher Update on 15 August 2023 (at launch, only players who purchased the game on Steam, GOG.com or Epic Games Store could play with each other, while Windows Apps and Xbox Series players were separated in their own cross-play segment).

The Darkest Files is a historical investigation game set in Germany in 1956, in the aftermath of the Second World War. Players take on the role of Esther Katz, a young prosecutor tasked with reopening unsolved murder cases linked to Nazi crimes. Despite the war ending over a decade earlier, many atrocities remain buried, and Esther's mission is to bring long-overdue justice to the victims.The game follows two murder investigations inspired by real historical events. Players collect evidence, interrogate witnesses and suspects, and piece together timelines to build cases that can stand up in court. Success requires carefully comparing testimonies, identifying inconsistencies, and constructing a clear sequence of events to present during trials. The narrative highlights both the personal and political challenges of confronting the remnants of Nazism in post-war Europe.Much of the game unfolds in Esther's Berlin office, where players interact with colleagues, examine documents, and prepare for legal proceedings.
